{{Other uses|Pitch (disambiguation){{!}}Pitch}}
An '''elevator pitch''', '''elevator speech''', or '''elevator statement''' is a short description of an idea, product, company, or oneself that explains the concept in a way such that any listener can understand it in a short period of time. This description typically explains who the product/company is for, what it does, why it is needed, and how it will get done. For the latter, when explaining an individual, the description generally explains one’s skills and goals, and why they would be a productive and beneficial person to have on a team or within a company/project. An elevator pitch does not have to include all of these components, but it usually does at least explain what the idea, product, company, or person is and why it/they are valuable.
An elevator pitch can be used to entice an investor, executive in a company, or explain an idea to a founder’s parents. The goal is simply to convey the overall concept or topic in an exciting way. Unlike a [[Sales_presentation|sales pitch]], there may not be a clear buyer/seller relationship.
The name—elevator pitch—reflects the idea that it should be possible to deliver the summary in the time span of an elevator ride, or approximately thirty seconds to two minutes.
== Background information and history == There are many origin stories for the elevator pitch or elevator speech. One commonly-known origin story is that of Ilene Rosenzweig and Michael Caruso, two former journalists in the 90s. According to Rosenzweig, Caruso was a senior editor at [[Vanity_Fair_(magazines)|Vanity Fair]] and was continuously attempting to pitch story ideas to the Editor-In-Chief at the time, but could never pin her down long enough to do so simply because she was always on the move.<ref>http://presentingrob.blogspot.com/2016/01/elevator-pitches-brief-history.html</ref> So, in order to pitch her ideas, Caruso would join her during short free periods of time she had, such as on an elevator ride. Thus, the concept of an elevator pitch was created, as says Rosenzweig.
However, there is another known potential origin story that dates back prior to the story of Rosenzweig and Caruso. [[Philip_B._Crosby#Works|Philip Crosby]], author of “The Art of Getting Your Own Sweet Way” (1972) and “Quality Is Still Free,” (1996) suggested individuals should have a pre-prepared speech that can deliver information regarding themselves or a quality that they can provide within a short period of time, namely the amount of time of an elevator ride for if an individual finds themselves on an elevator with a prominent figure.<ref>http://www.the-confidant.info/2012/the-history-of-the-elevator-speech/</ref> Essentially, an elevator pitch, or elevator speech, is meant to allow an individual to pitch themselves or an idea to a person who is high up in a company, with very limited time.
Crosby, who worked as a quality test technician, and then later as the Director of Quality at [[ITT_Inc.|International Telephone and Telegraph]], recounted how an elevator pitch could be used to push for change within the company.<ref>http://asq.org/quality-progress/2011/05/one-good-idea-going-up.html</ref> He planned a speech regarding the change he wanted to see and waited at the ITT headquarters elevator. Crosby stepped onto an elevator with the [[Chief_executive_officer|CEO]] of the company in order to deliver his speech. Once they reached the floor in which the CEO was getting off, Crosby was asked to deliver a full presentation on the topic at a meeting for all of the general managers.
The concept of an elevator pitch, as created by Crosby, did not receive much popularity until two statisticians, Gerry Hahn from [[General Electric]] and Tom Boardman, a professor at the [[University_of_Colorado|University or Colorado]], started to push the concept onto other statisticians. The two pushed this concept in order to help other statisticians in promoting what they have to offer. Boardman pushed the concept much further than Hahn, resulting in the elevator pitch, or elevator speech, ultimately being linked to Boardman and his professional life.
Another origin story for the elevator pitch is from [[Elisha_Otis|Elisha Graves Otis]], the inventor of a device meant for elevator safety, which dates back to the 1850s. In 1852, Otis began developing a device that would improve the safety of elevators, specifically related to the hoists used to lift heavy equipment to upper floors.<ref>https://buildingpharmabrands.com/2013/03/29/the-first-ever-elevator-pitch/</ref> The device was created out of steel wagon spring meshing and provided a backup catch and hold mechanism if the rope lifting the elevator gave way. In 1854, in the Crystal Palace Exposition in New York in front of a big audience, Otis revealed his device. He did so by lifting an elevator, like normal, but as it was positioned approximately halfway up the elevator shaft, the rope was cut. The elevator platform was held in place by Otis’ device. This can be known as the first elevator pitch ever.
== Aspects of an Elevator Pitch ==
An elevator pitch is meant to last the duration of an elevator ride, which can vary in length from approximately 15 seconds to two minutes. Therefore, the main focus of an elevator pitch should be making it short and direct. According to the Idaho Business Review<ref>https://idahobusinessreview.com/2012/02/22/the-elevator-pitch-for-every-professional/</ref>, the first two sentences of any elevator pitch are the most important, and should hook or grab the attention of the listener(s). Information in an elevator pitch, due to the limited amount of time, should be condensed in order to express the most important ideas or concepts within the allotted time. [[File:Business_agreement_handshake_at_coffee_shop.jpg|thumb|225x225px|Business agreement at coffee shop]] Furthermore, the Idaho Business Review suggests individuals who use an elevator pitch deliver it using simple language, and avoiding statistics or other language that may disrupt the focus of the listener. Bloomberg Businessweek suggests that an important lesson to think about when giving an elevator pitch is to “adjust the pitch to the person who is listening, and refine it as you and your business continue to grow and change.”<ref>http://www.mrgriffin.org/FHSWEB/ENT/articles/ThePerfectElevatorPitch.pdf</ref> When delivering an elevator pitch, individuals are encouraged to remain flexible and adaptable, and to be able to deliver the pitch in a genuine and fluent fashion. By doing so, the intended audience of the pitch will likely be able to follow the information, and will not interpret it as being too scripted.
== Advantages of utilizing Elevator Pitches ==
Advantages to conducting an elevator pitch, or elevator speech, include convenience and simplicity. For instance, elevator pitches can be given on short notice and without much preparation due to the pre-planning of the content being delivered within said pitch.<ref>https://idahobusinessreview.com/2012/02/22/the-elevator-pitch-for-every-professional/</ref> Furthermore, elevator pitches allow the individual who is giving the pitch the ability to simplify the content and deliver it in a less complicated manner by providing the information in a cut-down fashion that gets right to the point.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/36831/wow-project|publisher=[[FastCompany]]|title=The Wow Project|accessdate=2018-03-21}}</ref>
==See also== * [[High concept]] * [[Mission statement]] * [[Vision statement]] * [[Business plan]] * [[SWOT analysis]]

'''Experience management''' is the activity where organizations measure and improve the various experiences they provide, not only to customers, but to all their [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] like vendors, suppliers, employees, and shareholders. It is premised on the idea that experiences are a distinct economic offering, that create economic value and competitive advantage.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 24 March 2017|url = https://hbr.org/1998/07/welcome-to-the-experience-economy|title = Welcome to the Experience Economy|publisher = Harvard Business Review|author = B. Joseph Pine II and James H. Gilmore|date = July–August 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 March 2017|url = http://opusresearch.net/wordpress/2011/07/12/avaya-updates-its-suite-of-experience-management-software/|title = Avaya Updates Its Suite of Experience Management Software|publisher = Opus Research|author = Dan Miller|date = 12 July 2011}}</ref>
Organizations are increasingly collecting experience data as opposed to operational data, since experiences are seen as a [[competitive advantage]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 24 March 2017|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/brucerogers/2017/03/02/ryan-smiths-qualtrics-capitalizes-on-the-rise-of-the-experience-economy/#1e9a9d276221|title = Ryan Smith's Qualtrics Capitalizes On The Rise Of The 'Experience Economy'|publisher = Forbes |author = Bruce Rogers|date = 2 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 March 2017|url = http://www.haaga-helia.fi/en/opinto-opas/opintojaksokuvaukset/DES8RB024|title = Experience Management|publisher = Haaga-Helia}}</ref> Experience management platforms provide various services to automate the process of identifying and improving experiences across an organization.<ref name=Signage />
Broader than [[customer experience]], experience management now encompasses customer experience along with other areas, such as [[brand management|brand experience]], [[employee experience design|employee experience]] and product experience, which are all seen as interrelated.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 24 March 2017|url = http://www.marketing-trends-congress.com/archives/2010/Materiali/DoctoralColloquium/Kreuzer.pdf|title = An embodied cognition approach to the study of consumer brand knowledge|publisher = Marketing Trends Congress|author = Maria Kreuzer|date = November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 24 March 2017|url = https://www.amazon.com/Enhancing-Employee-Experience-Organizational-contribute/dp/3639138163|title = Enhancing the Employee Experience: Organizational practices that contribute to employee engagement|publisher = VDM Verlag|author = Linda Heska|date = 10 April 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 29 March 2017|url = http://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/marketing-and-sales/our-insights/building-a-design-driven-culture|title = Building a design-driven culture|publisher = McKinsey&Company|author = Jennifer Kilian, Hugo Sarrazin, and Hyo Yeon|date = September 2015}}</ref>
==History==
In 1994 Steve Haeckel and Lou Carbone collaborated on a seminal early article on experience management, titled "Engineering Customer Experiences," where they defined experience as "the 'take-away' impression formed by people's encounters with products, services and businesses — a perception produced when humans consolidate [[sense|sensory information]]." They argued that the new approach must focus on total experience as the key customer [[value proposition]].<ref name=Schmitt />
The concept reached a wide audience in 1999, when it was popularized by B. Joseph Pine II and James H. Gilmore in their book ''[[The Experience Economy|Experience Economy]]''.<ref name=Schmitt>{{cite book|last = Schmitt|first = Bernd |date = 2011|title = Experience Marketing: Concepts, Frameworks and Consumer Insights|url = https://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/sites/globalbrands/files/Experience%20Marketing%20-%20Schmitt%20-%20Foundations%20and%20Trends%202011.pdf|publisher = Columbia Business School|page = 87}}</ref> In the same year, [[Bernd Schmitt]] published ''Experiential Marketing: How to Get Customers to Sense, Feel, Think, Act, and Relate to Your Company and Brands.''<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 March 2017|url = https://www8.gsb.columbia.edu/researcharchive/articles/335|title = Experiential Marketing: How to Get Customers to Sense, Feel, Think, Act, and Relate to Your Company and Brands|publisher = Columbia Business School|author = Bernd Schmitt|date = 1999}}</ref>
In the 2000s, experience management emerged as a complex field unifying the experiences of brands, employees, products and more. It was acknowledged that generating new experiences for end customers requires designing better experiences for internal players of an organization. Value is created by focusing on the experiences of everyone involved in or affected by a new offer, such as customers, employees, suppliers, and other [[stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 29 March 2017|url = https://hbr.org/2010/10/building-the-co-creative-enterprise|title = Building the Co-Creative Enterprise|publisher = Harvard Business Review|author = Venkat Ramaswamy and Francis Gouillart|date = October 2010}}</ref>
==Management==
To create and manage the experiences, businesses must evaluate, implement, integrate, and build experiences from a fragmented landscape.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 March 2017|url = https://www.forrester.com/report/Vendor+Landscape+Digital+Experience+Platforms/-/E-RES104302|title = Vendor Landscape: Digital Experience Platforms|publisher = Forrester|author = Mark Grannan, Danielle Geoffroy|date = 16 May 2016}}</ref> Such needs are met by experience management platforms, which help automate the process of measuring and improving experiences across an organization by coordinating content, customer data and core services, and unifying marketing, commerce and service processes.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 March 2017|url = https://www.loyalty360.org/loyalty-today/article/11-tech-trends-you-can-bet-your-customer-experienc|title = 11 Tech Trends You Can Bet Your Customer Experience Budgets On, Today through 2020...|publisher = Loyalty 360|author = MCorpCX|date = 3 February 2017}}</ref><ref name=Signage>{{cite web|accessdate= 25 March 2017|url = https://www.digitalsignagetoday.com/articles/intel-webinar-zooms-in-on-digital-experience-management-platforms-2/|title = Intel webinar zooms in on digital experience management platforms|publisher = Digital Signage Today|author = Bradley Cooper|date = 21 March 2017}}</ref>
Experience management platforms compare multiple layers of data and statistics to enable organizations to identify any experience gaps. They connect [[operational database]]s with human feedback, analyzing respondents' emotions, beliefs, and sentiments for a holistic view of the experiences they provide. Their methods include [[artificial intelligence]], [[predictive analytics]], and [[statistical models]].<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 25 March 2017|url = http://www.heraldextra.com/business/local/qualtrics-quantifies-and-enhances-the-experience-economy-in-new-platform/article_92d96208-2556-5a04-9aad-5172da9d412f.html|title = Qualtrics quantifies and enhances the 'experience economy' in new platform|publisher = Daily Herald|author = Karissa Neely|date = 2 March 2017}}</ref>
==Other uses==
While the term ''experience management'' is predominantly used in business, it has another meaning. It is used for a special kind of [[knowledge management]] that deals with collecting, modeling, storing, reusing, evaluating, and maintaining experience.<ref>{{cite book|last = Bergmann|first = Ralph|date = 2002|title = Experience Management|url = https://books.google.hr/books?id=rq-qCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=%22experience+management%22+-customer&source=bl&ots=YaG7Y6gPuC&sig=kc-SBM0Xwmsx6C2Z7lfOkMGhpCg&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwje_v759-_SAhVmKpoKHVvxB1k4ChDoAQhoMAg#v=onepage&q=%22experience%20management%22%20-customer&f=false|publisher = Springer|location = Google Books|page = 1}}</ref> In that sense, the term is interchangeable with ''expertise management''.<ref>{{cite web|accessdate = 24 March 2017|url = https://info.legalsolutions.thomsonreuters.com/signup/newsletters/practice-innovations/2015-mar/article4.aspx|title = Experience Management: Build, Buy, or Abandon?|publisher = Legal Solutions|author = Lisa Gianakos|date = March 2015}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=August 2011}} In [[Business law|business or commercial law]], an '''extraordinary resolution''' or '''special resolution'''<ref>Some jurisdictions use both terms, but meaning slightly different things. For example, in the United Kingdom, an extraordinary resolution is a resolution passed by not less than 75% of the members, and a special resolution is a resolution passed by the same majority, but having given then members not less than 21 days' notice of the intention to put the resolution to a vote, see section 378 of the [[Companies Act 1985]]</ref> is a [[Resolution (law)|resolution]] passed by the [[stockholder|shareholders]] of a [[company (law)|company]] by a greater majority than is required to pass an [[ordinary resolution]]. The precise figures vary in different countries, but commonly an extraordinary resolution must be affirmed by not less than 75% of members casting votes, whereas an ordinary resolution only requires a bare majority.
Extraordinary resolutions are generally only required in certain specific situations required by statute. For example, in the [[United Kingdom]], to [[Liquidation#Voluntary liquidation|liquidate]] a company voluntarily on the ground that it cannot by reason of its insolvency continue its business, requires an extraordinary resolution.
However, in certain circumstances a company may wish to amend its [[Company (law)#Corporate constitution|constitutional documents]] to provide that an extraordinary resolution needs to be passed prior to the company engaging in any reserved matters, purely as a matter of internal organisational control.

==Early life==
Boccardi was born in Milan, Italy in October 1967. His father was the founder of the Istituto Finanziario Ambrosiano, a financial institution with interests in construction, real estate, and insurance. Boccardi attended the Leone XIII school in Milan, and then the Ophenaimer. He continued his studies in the United States, attending [[Villanova Preparatory School]], in Ojai, California, but was unable to finish his junior year when his family’s holding company's collapsed.
At age 19 Boccardi established himself as a [[commodities trader]] in Monte Carlo. In his early twenties he began to invest in condominium development in Italy and in the South of France.<ref>[http://www.ilgiornale.it/news/ecco-michael-tiranno-po-padrino-e-po-007.html Ecco Michael Tiranno via Il Giornale]</ref><ref>[http://www.affaritaliani.it/giochiescommesse/legginews.asp?id=140611115921&refresh_ce L'America Punta sull' online Italiano via Affari Italiani]</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2008/aug/28/man-who-would-be-king/|title=The man who would be king|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-societe/2007-01-16/casinos-jeux-brouilles/920/0/6031|title=Archives - Le Point.fr|first=Le Point,|last=magazine|website=Le Point.fr}}</ref><ref>[http://rockdirt.com/john-mayor-gets-drum-lessons-from-scott-phillips/4055/ Fabrizio Boccardi Hosts Party]</ref>
==Las Vegas casinos== [[File:L-2877635128.jpg|thumb|upright|left|New Frontier Casino]] [[File:Desert Inn.JPG|thumb|upright|left|Desert Inn]] [[File:B-987349707.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Riviera]] Boccardi has attempted to buy a Las Vegas casino, since 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2001/0528/060a.html|title=Long Live the King|first=RiShawn|last=Biddle|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nevadabusiness.com/issues/NBMDecember1999ViewIssue.pdf|title=Nevada Business Journal Up Front Pg. 8|publisher=}}</ref>At that time, he signed an agreement to buy the New Frontier Hotel & Casino on the Las Vegas Strip, for $270 million owned at the time by [[Phil Ruffin]]. The price Boccardi was willing to pay in 1999 for the aged New Frontier Hotel & Casino, was considered too high by the lenders and gaming analysts as a result Boccardi was forced to pull out during due diligence and terminate the agreement with Ruffin. Phil Ruffin sold the New Frontier to El Ad Properties in 2007 at more than $1.2 billion, the 36 Frontier acres sold for more than $33 million an acre.<ref>[http://www.hotel-online.com/News/PressReleases1999_4th/Oct99_LVGrowingMarket.html Boccardi Capital intends to build something bigger than a Megaresort via Hotel Online]</ref><ref>[https://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2000/mar/14/200-million-bid-for-desert-inn-called-flaky/ 200 million bid for Desert Inn via The Las Vegas Sun 03/14/2000]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.lasvegassun.com/news/1998/dec/11/french-italians-team-up-on-nevada-casino-complex/|title=French, Italians team up on Nevada casino complex|date=11 December 1998|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://lasvegassun.com/news/1999/oct/07/bullish-european-investors-eye-casinos/|title=Bullish European investors eye casinos|date=7 October 1999|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article/magnate-stays-quiet-about-plans-134686|title=Magnate Stays Quiet About Plans|website=www.casinocitytimes.com}}</ref>
In 2000, Boccardi offered $200 million for the Desert Inn Hotel & Casino, but his offer was considered too low by owners Starwood Hotel & Resorts and was then sold to Las Vegas casino owner [[Steve Wynn]] for $275 million. <ref>[http://andyholtmann.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/Casino-Company-Mergers-CJ-July-2000.pdf Wynn Begins Again with Desert Inn via Casino Journal]</ref><ref>[http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article/steve-wynns-interest-in-the-desert-inn-is-confirmed-134068 Steve Wynn's Interest in the Desert Inn is Confirmed] Casino City Times, retrieved 19 April 2000</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB952997008931461490|title=Starwood Receives $200 Million Offer For Casino but May Reject It as Too Low|first=Christina|last=Binkley|date=14 March 2000|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref> <ref>[https://http NVESTOR FIRM MAKES OFFER FOR LAS VEGAS CASINO, INN] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114075411/https://http/ |date=January 14, 2016 }} Orlando Sentinel, retrieved March 15, 2000</ref><ref>[http://articles.mcall.com/2000-03-15/business/3288282_1_desert-inn-nortel-xros Desert Inn/morning call via Tribune 03/15/2000]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/2000/03/15/business/company-news-starwood-rejects-a-200-million-offer-for-desert-inn.html?referer=|title=COMPANY NEWS; In 2003, Boccardi bid $8.50 per share for control of Riviera Holdings, owners of the Riviera Hotel & Casino on the Las Vegas Strip and a casino in Black Hawk, Colorado. ==Litigation== In April 2004, DE Shaw Laminar Portfolios announced in its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) pending strategic discussions with Fabrizio Boccardi of Las Vegas regarding the Riviera Casino, and bought 10% in [[Riviera Holdings]] from [[Donald Trump]].<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB104932802974338600 Italian Investor Bids For Riviera Holdings] Retrieved April 3, 2003</ref><ref>[http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2004/aug/23/board-rejects-offer-to-sell-riviera-holdings/ Board rejects offer to sell Riviera Holdings] Las Vegas Sun Times, retrieved Aug 23, 2004</ref><ref>http://online.barrons.com/articles/SB108276156021592290</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.lasvegassun.com/news/2003/jul/23/riviera-drops-poison-pill/|title=Riviera drops poison pill|date=23 July 2003|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article/firm-sued-over-buyout-offer-132984|title=Firm Sued Over Buyout Offer|website=www.casinocitytimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.fultoncountynews.com/news/2008-12-25/features/089.html#.WaTBgyMrLJx|title=Las Vegas Is Just A Page Away This Holiday Season With "The Tyrant" - Fulton County News|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-1033697|title=ODISEA DE UN ITALIANO EN POS DE LAS VEGAS|first=Casa Editorial El|last=Tiempo|publisher=}}</ref>In May 2004, in subsequent filings with the SEC, DE Shaw Laminar Portfolios announced the termination of its discussions with Boccardi regarding Riviera Holdings. Stock of Riviera Holdings trading on the American Stock Exchange subsequently split 3 for 1 and was trading at a substantial premium.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=alHchVWaNXQA|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130817073138/http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=alHchVWaNXQA|deadurl=yes|title=Boccardi Capital Systems Appeals Decision to Dismiss Its Case - Bloom…|date=17 August 2013|archivedate=17 August 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[https://www.juralindex.com/de-shaw-laminar-portfolios.html Boccardi Capital Vs De Shaw Laminar Portfolios via Jural Index retrieved 12/31/2017]</ref>
In 2005 Boccardi Capital Systems filed suit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in Manhattan, against DE Shaw Laminar Portfolios for breach of contract and other allegations in connection with Riviera Holdings, asking for compensation of approximately $140 million. The suit was finally dismissed in February 2009, and despite an appeal that Boccardi Capital filed immediately thereafter, the judgment was reaffirmed in December 2009 by the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.law360.com/m/articles/138620/2nd-circ-mucks-ex-partner-s-suit-over-casino-venture|title=2nd Circ. Mucks Ex-Partner's Suit Over Casino Venture - Law360|website=www.law360.com}}</ref> <ref>[http://globaldocuments.morningstar.com/DocumentLibrary/Document/c38b521d5d1b6373.msdoc/original/y00698sc13dza.txt MORNINGSTAR]</ref><ref>[https://www.barrons.com/articles/SB108276156021592290 BARRON'S]</ref><ref>[http://www.rgtonline.com/article/another-buyer-emerges-to-make-offer-for-riviera-holdings-51265?CategoryName=business&SubCategoryName= http://www.rgtonline.com]</ref><ref>[https://www.leagle.com/decision/infco20091209130 "Boccardi Capital Appeals Decision” via Leagle.com retrieved on 01/11/2018]</ref> ==Settled Dispute==
Twentieth Century Fox and King Midas World Entertainment found a peaceful resolution in 2014 regarding the TYRANT Mark. Both parties called on to refrain from challenging each other’s mark, with FX’s “Tyrant” TV serie based on the story of an American family drawn into Middle Eastern turmoil, and King Midas’ “Tyrant” a Las Vegas-based superhero property created by Fabrizio Boccardi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvweek.com/tvbizwire/2014/07/companies-settle-differences-i/|title=Companies Settle Differences in Struggle Over ‘Tyrant’ - TVWeek|website=www.tvweek.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/tyrant-agreement-reached-between-twentieth-century-fox-and-king-midas-world-entertainment/|title='Tyrant' Agreement Reached Between Twentieth Century Fox and King Midas World Entertainment|date=21 July 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[https://www.marketwatch.com/story/tyrant-pact-reached-2014-07-29 Tyrant Pact via MarketWatch]</ref> ==Venture Capital==

==The Tyrant Knight== [[File:Fabrizio Boccardi Business.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Fabrizio Boccardi at Santa Monica Airport in April 2003]] The Tyrant Knight is Boccardi's franchised fictional character, first appearing in 2008 in the book "The Seven Sins: The Tyrant Ascending," written by [[Jon Land]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.lvsun.com/news/2010/apr/05/businessman-fabrizio-boccardi-bets-big-vegas/|title=Businessman Fabrizio Boccardi bets big on Vegas|date=5 April 2010|publisher=}}</ref> and published by Macmillan.<ref name="auto2"/>
Boccardi worked with Land to create the story, which is loosely inspired by Boccardi's own life.<ref name="auto3"/><ref>[https://lasvegasweekly.com/ae/print/2008/aug/28/sin-tillating/ A Sin-tillating Ride]</ref>
In 2017, famed Cult Classic favorite and blockbuster film Director Chuck Russell was attached to Direct and help to write the screenplay for the film.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/05/chuck-russell-writing-directing-movie-the-seven-sins-book-fabrizio-boccardi-1202087708/|title=Chuck Russell Signs On To Write And Direct ‘The Seven Sins’|first=Anita|last=Busch|date=10 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/chuck-russell-seven-sins-director-1202422131/|title=‘The Mask’ Director Chuck Russell Boards Las Vegas Fantasy Movie ‘The Seven Sins’|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=10 May 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.pressreader.com/kuwait/arab-times/20140724/283433484662557 The Superhero Tyrant via The Arab Times retrieved 12/31/2017]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://knpr.org/knpr/2008-08/seven-sins-tyrant-ascending|title=The Seven Sins: The Tyrant Ascending|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://link.dclibrary.org/portal/The-Seven-Sins--the-tyrant-ascending-Jon/NRzJSYTFGyg/ ”The Seven Sins the Tyrant Ascending” via Public Library District of Columbia received 01/07/2018]</ref><ref>[http://www.bookloons.com/cgi-bin/Review.asp?bookid=9209 "The Seven Sins Review” via BookLoons retrieved on 01/07/2018]</ref><ref>[https://www.benzinga.com/pressreleases/12/05/b2607831/the-beanstalk-group-and-king-midas-world-entertainment-enter-into-brand THE BEANSTALK GROUP AND KING MIDAS WORLD ENTERTAINMENT ENTER INTO BRANDING AGREEMENT VIA Benzinga News retrieved on 09/24/2018]</ref> ===Book series===
In 2008, ''[[The Seven Sins: The Tyrant Ascending]]'' was published by Forge Books/Saint Martin's Press.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/entertainment/articles/2012/09/14/in-tyrant-creator-aims-to-meld-fiction-fact|title=In Tyrant Creator Aims To Meld Fiction Fact|publisher=}}</ref> The Library Journal selected ''The Seven Sins: The Tyrant Ascending'' as a "Best Thriller of 2008."<ref>[http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6620714.html Best Books 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130113013656/http://www.libraryjournal.com/article/CA6620714.html |date=2013-01-13 }} Retrieved Dec 08, 2008</ref><ref>[http://link.dclibrary.org/portal/The-Seven-Sins--the-tyrant-ascending-Jon/NRzJSYTFGyg/ The Seven Sins : the tyrant ascending - District of Columbia Public Library - retrieved on 10/28/2018]</ref>

==Comics==
DC Entertainment is developing the Comics based on a publishing license provided to DC by King Midas World Entertainment. ==Film== A major production for a feature film is in active development in Hollywood based on the franchised character of Michael Tiranno, the Tyrant Knight. The film will be based on the blended adaptation of Black Scorpion and its predecessor, The Seven Sins, which both have also been licensed to DC Comics for comic books and graphic novels publications worldwide. In 2017, famed Cult Classic favorite and blockbuster film Director Chuck Russell was attached to Direct and help to write the screenplay for the film titled "The Seven Sins: Dawn of the Tyrant Knight" as reported by the movie database on IMDb and in the press.<ref>[http://www.shockya.com/news/2010/01/22/the-seven-sins-coming-to-the-big-screen/ Seven Sins coming to the big screen via Shock Ya 1/22/2010]</ref><ref>[https://movieweb.com/the-seven-sins-the-tyrant-ascending-in-the-works/ The Seven Sins the Tyrant Ascending in the Works via MovieWeb]</ref><ref>[https://www.moviefone.com/2008/07/23/what-happens-when-terrorists-attack-vegas/ When Terrorists Attack Vegas Seven Sins]</ref><ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Industry-Buzz-3197493.php Michael Tiranno the New Corleone? via SFGate]</ref> <ref>[https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/pair-bets-seven-sins-116144 Pair Bets On Seven Sins]</ref><ref>[https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/alexander-scribe-boards-seven-sins-19768 Alexander Scribe Boards Seven Sins]</ref><ref name="us.macmillan.com"/><ref name="yahoo.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forcesofgeek.com/2015/05/fog-chats-with-author-jon-land-abou.html|title=Chats with Author Jon Land - Forces of Geek|website=www.forcesofgeek.com}}</ref><ref>http://www.chicagochronicle.com/index.php/sid/231730369</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2008/08/arnolds-voice-i/|title=Arnold's Voice in Terminator? ==Seven Sins Megaresort==
[[File:Fabrizio Boccardi.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Fabrizio Boccardi (pictured right) at the Skylofts at the MGM Grand overlooking the Las Vegas strip during an interview in March 2018.]]
Fabrizio Boccardi has announced plans to use his media properties such as Tiranno, Tyrant and Tyrant Knight to launch a global gaming and hospitality brand which will include the construction of the Seven Sins Megaresort, the same casino depicted in the Michael Tiranno the Tyrant book series, films and comics. In an interview with Robin Leach via the Review Journal in 2017, Boccardi confirmed that the timing for his casino and hospitality plans to be realized will be primarily determined by the level of success of the film property with the announced title The Seven Sins, a story of money, power and a new type of superhero based on adaptations inspired by the book series of Michael Tiranno the Tyrant aka the Tyrant Knight.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/entertainment/entertainment-columns/robin-leach/comedy-vietnamese-fusion-at-black-sheep/|title=Comedy & Dolls at Planet Hollywood; Vietnamese fusion at Black Sheep|date=1 June 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/celebrity/news/tyrant-creator-aims-meld-fiction-fact-214957826.html|title=In 'Tyrant,' creator aims to meld fiction, fact|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-acquires-rights-to-prose-antihero-the-tyrant/|title=DC Comics acquires rights to prose antihero The Tyrant|date=10 June 2011|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://knpr.org/dc-blog/so-its-novel-and-comic-book-and-hotel-casino|title=So, it's a novel AND comic book AND hotel-casino?|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://oneenergydream.blogspot.com/2010/01/fabrizio-boccardi-la-vita-e-le-opere.html|title=Fabrizio Boccardi: la vita e le opere!|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-73230651.html|title=Las Vegas Review-Journal Gaming Chips Column.|date=15 April 2001|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[https://knpr.org/taxonomy/term/12269/all Visionary Investor Fabrizio Boccardi Interview via KNPR Radio Nevada retrieved on 06/13/2018]</ref>
==Other Media Properties==
===Dark Light Dawn===
It was announced Fabrizio Boccardi<ref name="auto4">{{cite web|url=https://m.imdb.com/name/nm9038106/bio?ref=mmnovbio|title=Fabrizio Boccardi|website=IMDb}}</ref> created a new media property named Dark Light Dawn. The first book in the series has been announced for publication in North America by Macmillan Publishing Group on August 1, 2017. The book is written by Jon Land and created and owned by Fabrizio Boccardi. According to media articles Dark Light Dawn is also set for other media such as film and television.
Inspired by recent geopolitical events, rising terrorism, and religious conflicts, the novel meshes an action-packed, paranormal tale with an entirely fresh take on the action horror thriller genre. Dark Light Dawn creatively blends scientific principles, superstition, biblical elements and the inexplicable of the universe, culminating in a celebration of free will and the power of human nature itself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebigthrill.org/2017/07/dark-light-dawn-by-jon-land-and-created-by-fabrizio-boccardi/|title=Dark Light: Dawn by Jon Land and created by Fabrizio revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[William Gross]] (link changed to [[Bill H. Gross]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
:''Not to be confused with [[economic repression]], a type of political repression.'' '''Financial repression''' comprises "policies that result in savers earning returns below the rate of [[inflation]]" in order to allow banks to "provide cheap loans to companies and governments, reducing the burden of repayments".<ref name=bloom>{{cite news|title=China Savers Prioritized Over Banks by PBOC|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-11-25/china-savers-prioritized-over-banks-by-pboc-as-repression-eases.html|work=Bloomberg|date=November 25, 2014}}</ref> It can be particularly effective at liquidating [[government debt]] [[Denomination (currency)|denominated]] in domestic currency.<ref name=redux/> It can also lead to a large expansions in debt "to levels evoking comparisons with the excesses that generated [[Japan]]’s [[Lost Decade (Japan)|lost decade]] and the [[1997 Asian financial crisis|Asian financial crisis]]" in 1997.<ref name=bloom/>
The term was introduced in 1973 by [[Stanford]] economists Edward S. Shaw and [[Ronald I. McKinnon]]<ref>Shaw, Edward S. ''Financial Deepening in Economic Development''. New York: Oxford University Press, 1973</ref><ref>McKinnon, Ronald I. ''Money and Capital in Economic Development''. Washington, D.C.: [[Brookings Institution]], 1973</ref> in order to "disparage growth-inhibiting policies in [[emerging markets]]".
== Mechanism ==
Financial repression consists of the following:<ref name="logd"/> #Explicit or indirect capping of interest rates, such as on government debt and deposit rates (e.g., [[Regulation Q]]). #Government ownership or control of domestic banks and financial institutions with barriers that limit other institutions from entering the market. #High [[reserve requirements]]. #Creation or maintenance of a [[Captive market |captive domestic market]] for government debt, achieved by requiring banks to hold government debt via [[capital requirements]], or by prohibiting or disincentivising alternatives. #Government restrictions on the transfer of assets abroad through the imposition of [[capital controls]].
These measures allow governments to issue debt at lower interest rates. A low [[nominal interest rate]] can reduce debt servicing costs, while [[negative interest rates|negative real interest rates]] erodes the real value of government debt.<ref name="logd"/> Thus, financial repression is most successful in liquidating debts when accompanied by inflation and can be considered a form of [[taxation]],<ref>Reinhart, Carmen M. and Rogoff, Kenneth S., [https://books.google.com/books?id=ak5fLB24ircC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false ''This Time is Different: Eight Centuries of Financial Folly'']. Princeton and Oxford: Princeton University Press, 2008, p. 143</ref> or alternatively a form of [[debasement]].<ref>[[Bill H. Gross|Bill Gross]], [http://www.pimco.com/EN/Insights/Pages/The-Caine-Mutiny-Part-2.aspx "The Caine Mutiny Part 2"], PIMCO</ref>
The size of the financial repression tax was computed for 24 [[emerging market]]s from 1974 to 1987. The results showed that financial repression exceeded 2% of GDP for seven countries, and greater than 3% for five countries. For five countries ([[India]], [[Mexico]], [[Pakistan]], [[Sri Lanka]], and [[Zimbabwe]]) it represented approximately 20% of [[tax revenue]]. In the case of [[Mexico]] financial repression was 6% of GDP, or 40% of tax revenue.<ref>Giovannini, Alberto and de Melo, Martha, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2117587 "Government Revenue from Financial Repression"], ''[[The American Economic Review]]'', Vol. 83, No. 4 Sep. 1993 (pp. 953-963)</ref>
Financial repression is categorized as "[[macroprudential policy|macroprudential regulation]]"—i.e., government efforts to "ensure the health of an entire financial system.<ref name=redux>Carmen M. Reinhart, Jacob F. Kirkegaard, and M. Belen Sbrancia, [http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/fandd/2011/06/pdf/reinhart.pdf "Financial Repression Redux"], IMF Finance and Development, June 2011, p. 22-26</ref>
==Examples== ===After World War II=== Financial repression "played an important role in reducing [[debt-to-GDP ratio]]s after [[World War II]]" by keeping [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|real]] interest rates for government debt below 1% for two-thirds of the time between 1945 and 1980, the United States was able to "inflate away" the large debt (122% of GDP) left over from the [[Great Depression]] and [[World War II]].<ref name=redux/> In the [[UK]], government debt declined from 216% of GDP in 1945 to 138% ten years later in 1955.<ref name=economist>{{cite news|title=The great repression|url=http://www.economist.com/node/18834259?story_id=18834259|work=The Economist|date=16 June 2011}}</ref> ===China=== [[China]]'s [[Economy of China|economic growth]] has been attributed to financial repression thanks to "low returns on savings and the cheap loans that it makes possible". This has allowed China to rely on savings-financed [[investment]]s for [[economic growth]]. However, because low returns also dampens [[consumer spending]], [[Household final consumption expenditure|household expenditures]] account for "a smaller share of [[GDP]] in China than in any other major economy".<ref name=bloom/> However, as of December 2014, the [[People’s Bank of China]] "started to undo decades of financial repression" and the government now allows Chinese savers to collect up to a 3.3% return on one-year deposits. At China's 1.6% inflation rate, this is a "high real-interest rate compared to other major economies”.<ref name=bloom/>
===After the 2008 economic recession=== In a 2011 [[NBER]] working paper, [[Carmen Reinhart]] and Maria Belen Sbrancia speculate on a possible return by governments to this form of debt reduction in order to deal with high debt levels following the [[2008 economic crisis]].<ref name="logd">Carmen M. Reinhart and M. Belen Sbrancia, [https://www.imf.org/external/np/seminars/eng/2011/res2/pdf/crbs.pdf "The Liquidation of Government Debt"], IMF, 2011, p. 19</ref>
"To get access to capital, [[Austria]] has restricted capital flows to foreign [[subsidiaries]] in central and eastern Europe. Select [[pension fund]]s have also been transferred to governments in [[France]], [[Portugal]], [[Ireland]] and [[Hungary]], enabling them to re-allocate toward [[sovereign bond]]s."<ref name=alli/>
==Criticism== Critics{{who|date=October 2016}} argue that if this view was true, investors (i.e., capital-seeking parties) would be inclined to demand capital in large quantities and would be buying capital goods from this capital. This high demand for capital goods would certainly lead to [[inflation]] and thus the [[central bank]]s would be forced to raise interest rates again. As a boom pepped by low interest rates fails to appear these days in industrialized countries, this is a sign that the low interest rates seem to be necessary to ensure an equilibrium on the capital market, thus to balance capital-supply—i.e., savers—on one side and capital-demand—i.e., investors and the government—on the other. This view argues that interest rates would be even lower if it were not for the high government debt ratio (i.e., capital demand from the government).
[[Free-market]] economists argue that financial repression [[Crowding out (economics)|crowds out]] private-sector investment, thus undermining growth. On the other hand, "[[postwar]] politicians clearly decided this was a price worth paying to cut debt and avoid outright [[Default (finance)|default]] or draconian spending cuts. And the longer the gridlock over fiscal reform rumbles on, the greater the chance that 'repression' comes to be seen as the least of all evils".<ref>[[Gillian Tett]], [http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/0af29588-7a5b-11e0-af64-00144feabdc0.html "Policymakers learn a new and alarming catchphrase"], ''Financial Times'', May 9, 2011</ref>
Also, financial repression has been called a “[[stealth tax]]” that "rewards debtors and punishes savers—especially [[Pensioner|retirees]]" because their investments will no longer generate the expected return, which is income for retirees.<ref name=alli>{{cite web|title=Financial Repression 101|url=http://us.allianzgi.com/EducationAndPlanning/InvestmentThemes/Pages/Financial_Repression101.aspx|website=[[Allianz]] Global Investors|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name=amerman>{{cite news|last1=Amerman|first1=Daniel|title=The 2nd Edge of Modern Financial Repression: Manipulating Inflation Indexes to Steal from Retirees & Public Workers|url=http://www.financialsense.com/contributors/daniel-amerman/2011/09/12/the-2nd-edge-of-modern-financial-repression|work=Financial Sense|date=September 12, 2011}}</ref> "One of the main goals of financial repression is to keep [[Real versus nominal value (economics)|nominal]] interest rates lower than they would be in more competitive markets. Other things equal, this reduces the government’s interest expenses for a given stock of debt and contributes to [[Government budget balance|deficit reduction]]. However, when financial repression produces negative [[real interest rate]]s (nominal rates below the inflation rate), it reduces or liquidates existing debts and becomes the equivalent of a tax—a [[Transfer payment|transfer]] from creditors (savers) to borrowers, including the government."<ref name=redux/>
==See also== {{columns|col1=
* [[Capital controls]] * [[Banking regulation]] * [[Bank reserves]] * [[Inflation tax]] * [[Indirect tax]] * [[Hidden tax]] |col2= '''Reform:''' * [[Internal devaluation]] |col3= '''General:''' * [[Sovereign debt]] * [[Financial regulation]] * [[Macroprudential policy]] * [[Debasement]] }}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Financial Repression}}

{{Anti-consumerism |Theories}} '''Hyperconsumerism''', '''hyper-consumerism''', '''hyperconsumption''' or '''hyper-consumption''' refer to the consumption of goods for non-functional purposes<ref name="Sirgy2001">{{cite book|author=M. Joseph Sirgy|title=Handbook of Quality-of-Life Research: An Ethical Marketing Perspective|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TxEHYNDzGO0C&pg=PA140|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=30 November 2001|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4020-0172-7|pages=140–}}</ref> and the associated significant pressure to consume those goods exerted by the modern, [[capitalist]] society, as those goods shape one's [[Identity (social science)|identity]].<ref name="Städtler2011"/><ref name="Tierney2009">{{cite book|author=John Tierney|title=Key Perspectives in Criminology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-u1NoSEEJR4C&pg=PA124|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=1 May 2009|publisher=McGraw-Hill International|isbn=978-0-335-22914-7|pages=124–}}</ref> [[Frenchy Lunning]] defines it curtly as "a [[consumerism]] for the sake of consuming."<ref name="Lunning2010">{{cite book|author=Frenchy Lunning|title=Fanthropologies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5d0Q9fdinQUC&pg=PA140|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=9 November 2010|publisher=U of Minnesota Press|isbn=978-0-8166-7387-2|pages=140–}}</ref>
==Characteristics== In a hyper-consumption society, "each social experience is mediated by market mechanisms", as market exchanges have spread to institutions in which they played lesser (if any) role previously, such as universities.<ref name="GabrielLang2006">{{cite book|author1=Yiannis Gabriel|author2=Tim Lang|title=The Unmanageable Consumer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NPA8OhyoHnAC&pg=PA71|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=9 May 2006|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-1-4129-1893-0|pages=71–}}</ref><ref name="BondebjergGolding2004">{{cite book|author1=Ib Bondebjerg|author2=Peter Golding|title=European Culture And The Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FJ9p6ms74AsC&pg=PT74|accessdate=6 February 2013|year=2004|publisher=Intellect Books|isbn=978-1-84150-111-6|pages=74–}}</ref>
===Personal identity===
Hyperconsumerism is fueled by [[brands]], as people often form deep attachment to product brands, which affects people's identity, and which pressure people to buy and consume their goods.<ref name="Städtler2011">{{cite book|author=Raphael Städtler|title=Celebrity Scandals and their Impact on Brand Image: A Study among Young Consumers: A Theoretical and Empirical Investigation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=geYcb_YZk4UC&pg=PA16|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=19 April 2011|publisher=GRIN Verlag|isbn=978-3-640-89715-5|page=16}}</ref><ref name="Sayers2008"/>
===Product lifecycle===
Another of the characteristics of hyperconsumerism is the constant pursuit of novelty, encouraging consumers to buy new and discard the old, seen particularly in [[fashion]], where the [[product lifecycle]] can be very short, measured sometimes in weeks only.<ref name="BondebjergGolding2004"/><ref name="Arnold2009">{{cite book|author=Chris Arnold|title=Ethical Marketing and The New Consumer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XgohhaXFMqcC&pg=PT30|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=27 October 2009|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-68546-4|page=30}}</ref>
===Conspicuous consumption===
In hyperconsumerism, goods are often [[status symbols]], as individuals buy them not so much to use them, as to [[Conspicuous consumption|display them to others]], sending associated meanings (such as displaying wealth).<ref name="Sirgy2001"/> However, according to other theorists, the need to consume in hyper-consumption society is driven less by competition with others than by their own [[hedonistic]] pleasure.<ref name="Paris2011">{{cite book|author=Chris Paris|title=Affluence, Mobility and Second Home Ownership|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rcnD5vXj-_AC&pg=PA17|accessdate=6 February 2013|year=2011|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-54891-5|pages=17–}}</ref>
===Religious characteristics===
Hyperconsumerism has been also said to have religious characteristics,<ref name="Bhaskar2010">{{cite book|author=Roy Bhaskar|title=Interdisciplinarity and Climate Change: Transforming Knowledge and Practice for Our Global Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xE2Oa2wKQ0YC&pg=PA240|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=25 January 2010|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-57387-0|pages=240–}}</ref> and have been compared to a new religion which enshrines consumerism above all, with elements of religious life being replaced by consumerist life: (going to) churches replaced by (going to) shopping malls, saints replaced by celebrities, penance replaced by shopping sprees, desire for better life after death replaced by desire for better life in the present, and so on.<ref name="Sayers2008">{{cite book|author=Mark Sayers|title=The Trouble With Paris: Following Jesus in a World of Plastic Promises|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2osXF-V9XhkC&pg=PA33|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=3 June 2008|publisher=Thomas Nelson Inc|isbn=978-1-4185-7460-4|pages=30–34}}</ref> Mark Sayers notes that hyperconsumerism has [[commercialized]] many religious symbols, giving an example of religious symbols worn as jewelry by non-believers.<ref name="Sayers2008"/>
==Criticism== Hyperconsumerism has been associated with [[cultural homogenization]], [[globalization]], [[Eurocentrism]], Eurocentric [[modernizations]], and consequently, the spread of [[Western culture]].<ref name="Ritzer2008">{{cite book|author=George Ritzer|title=The Blackwell Companion to Globalization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XKnmvRATtfAC&pg=PA140|accessdate=6 February 2013|date=15 April 2008|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=978-0-470-76642-2|page=140}}</ref> It has been blamed for environmental problems owing to excessive use of limited resources.<ref>{{cite web|author=Interview by Sophie Morris |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/green-living/think-you-love-shopping-its-the-marketing-scam-of-the-century-849922.html |title=Think you love shopping? It's the marketing scam of the century - Green Living - Environment |publisher=The Independent |date=2008-06-19 |accessdate=2013-02-18}}</ref><ref name="Ferrell2004">{{cite book|author=Jeff Ferrell|title=Cultural Criminology Unleashed|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JVcCn0PovvkC&pg=PA167|accessdate=6 February 2013|year=2004|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-1-904385-37-0|pages=167–}}</ref> It is seen as a symptom of [[overdevelopment]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/904209795|title=International encyclopedia of the social & behavioral sciences|others=Wright, James D.,|isbn=9780080970875|edition=Second|location=Amsterdam|oclc=904209795}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Commodification]] *[[Conspicuous consumption]] *[[Consumption (economics)]] *[[Hypermodernity]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Anti-corporate activism]] [[Category:Consumption]]

{{Infobox Software | name = IQTELL | developer = IQTELL.COM, LLC | operating_system = [[Web computing|Web]], [[Google Chrome|Chrome]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]] | genre = productivity software & personal task management | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] | website = [http://iqtell.com/ IQTELL] }}
'''IQTELL''' was a productivity app that allowed users to manage email, tasks, projects, calendars, contacts, [[Evernote|Evernotes]] and more in a single app. IQTELL was available as a web app, as well as an [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] app. All user information was automatically synced between all devices. iOS and Android apps supported offline access. The app could be used to implement concepts and techniques described in the book ''[[Getting Things Done]]'' by David Allen.<ref>[http://lifehacker.com/iqtell-puts-gtd-notes-and-email-in-a-single-productivi-1539006627 "IQTELL Puts GTD, Notes and Email in a Single Productivity App"]. ''Lifehacker''</ref>
==History== IQTELL was created by Ran Flam<ref>[http://www.baselinemag.com/careers/slideshows/how-to-deal-with-email-when-youre-on-vacation.html "How to Deal With Email When You're on Vacation"]. ''Base Line'', By Dennis McCafferty | 2014-07-03</ref> and released in 2013.<ref>[http://www.itproportal.com/2013/04/16/4-productivity-tools-help-you-get-things-done-iqtell-wunderlist-tracky-basecamp/ "4 Productivity tools to help you get things done: IQTell, Wunderlist, Tracky, Basecamp"]. ''IT Pro Portal'', 16 May 2013 By Kate Russell</ref>
In 2014, mobile apps for iOS and Android were released.<ref> [http://www.maclife.com/article/news/overnight_recap_google_maps_out_beta_iqtell_amazon_coin_android "Overnight Recap: Google Maps Out of Beta, IQTELL, Amazon Coin on Android"]. ''Mac Life'', February 20, 2014.</ref>
In 2015, Premium and Platinum subscription plans were introduced (while maintaining the free user version).
In April 2017, a new web app was launched.<ref>[https://iqtell.com/2017/04/launching-new-web-app/ "Launching our new web app"]. ''IQTell Productivity Blog'', April 5, 2017.</ref>
On July 31, 2017, all IQTell services have been closed.<ref>[https://iqtell.com/2017/06/the-future-of-iqtell/ "The future of IQTell"]. ''IQTell Productivity Blog'', June 29, 2017.</ref>
== Productivity Methods ==
IQTell was designed to fit in with the ''Getting Things Done'' (GTD) productivity methods. Users may have had utilized GTD lists, such as Inbox, Actions, Projects, Someday, Ticklers, and Reference information to process their Inbox items into relevant GTD lists.<ref name=tr>[http://www.techrepublic.com/article/iqtell-is-ready-to-super-charge-your-mobile-productivity/ "IQTELL is ready to super charge your mobile productivity"]. By Jack Wallen, ''Tech Republic'', February 26, 2014</ref><ref>[http://www.techrepublic.com/article/clear-your-head-while-quickly-navigating-your-inbox-with-iqtell-contexts/ "Clear your head while quickly navigating your inbox with IQTELL contexts"].By Jack Wallen. ''Tech Republic'', March 6, 2014</ref>
Using the web app, iOS and/or Android apps, users could deploy macros/shortcuts to quickly process their email.<ref name=muo>[http://www.makeuseof.com/tag/inbox-control-iqtell-might-answer/ "If Your Inbox Is Out of Control, IQTELL Might Be the Answer "]. ''MakeUseOf''. By Dann Albright on 26th March, 2014</ref> Email was turned into tasks (actions), projects, etc.<ref name=tr /> The original email was removed from the email inbox.<ref name=muo /> The email became a part of the items created (e.g. actions, project, etc.) and could also be viewed in the All Mail folder (if [[Gmail]]), or the Archive folder (if non-Gmail). Users had flexibility to use the out-of-the-box macros/shortcuts as well as edit/create additional macros.
IQTELL features included email, calendars, contacts, list management, sharing and collaboration with team members. All of the features were compatible with commonly used organization software such as Evernote<ref>[http://www.askyourandroid.com/applications/productivity-applications/iqtell-manage-your-emails-tasks-and-projects-the-smart-way/ "IQTELL: Manage your Emails, Projects and Tasks the smart way']. ''Ask Your Android''.</ref> and [[iCloud]].
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== Further reading ==
* AndroidGuys, February 20, 2014; [http://www.androidguys.com/2014/02/20/iqtell-marries-inbox-zero-gtd-new-app-app-day/ IQTELL marries ‘inbox zero’ and GTD in new app] * 148 Apps, February 19, 2014; [http://www.148apps.com/news/iqtell-updated-crossplatform-functionality-email-offline-mode/ IQTELL Updated With Cross-Platform Functionality, Email, an Offline Mode, and More] * Bitelia, September 12, 2013; [http://bitelia.com/2013/09/gestion-de-tareas-iqtell Mejora tu productividad uniende Get Things Done con Inbox Zero]
== External links == * [http://iqtell.com/ Official Website]

SafeBreach] | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Itzik Kotler''' is an [[Israel]]i [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]],{{cite news | last= | first=| title =TechNation Bezeq Launches Smart’ Home Monitoring System Featuring Camera and Door Monitors| newspaper =[[Haaretz]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =| date =9 July 2015| url =http://www.haaretz.com/business/1.665110| accessdate =21 September 2015}} [[inventor]],{{cite book | last =Ligh | first =Michael Hale |author2=Andrew Case|author3= Jamie Levy|author4=Aaron Walters | title =The Art of Memory Forensics: Detecting Malware and Threats in Windows, Linux, and Mac Memory | publisher =[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] | series = | volume = | edition =1 | date =28 July 2014 | location = | pages = | language = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=U1jOAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA712&lpg=PA712&dq=%22itzik+kotler%22&source=bl&ots=yhsDYCRU_n&sig=gTKUly7qoEVUVoeEXdX9yPpmoBA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBjgeahUKEwiblui71YvIAhXHA5IKHayuBgg#v=onepage&q=%22itzik%20kotler%22&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =978-1118825099 | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }}{{cite book | last =Grant | first =Nicholas |author2=Joseph Shaw II | title =Unified Communications Forensics: Anatomy of Common UC Attacks | publisher =Syngress | series = | volume = | edition = | date =7 October 2013 | location = | pages = | language = | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=9lmatCF6L7YC&pg=PA117&dq=%22itzik+kotler%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB0Q6AEwAGoVChMIsdOkkNmLyAIVhFSSCh3-FwkC#v=onepage&q=%22itzik%20kotler%22&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn = | mr = | zbl = | jfm = }} and [[Information security|information security specialist]]{{cite news | last= | first=| title =קבוצת Defcon Israel בכנס Hackathon ראשון| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language =Hebrew | publisher =Geektime| date =28 June 2011| url =http://www.geektime.co.il/defcon-israel-hackathon/| accessdate =21 September 2015}} who is the co-founder and [[Chief technology officer|CTO]] of [[SafeBreach]], an Israeli [[cybersecurity]] firm.{{cite news | last=Weinglass | first=Simona| title =What would your enemy do? Israeli cybersecurity firm SafeBreach raises $4m| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =Geektime| date =8 July 2015| url =http://www.geektime.com/2015/07/08/what-would-your-enemy-do-israeli-cybersecurity-firm-safebreach-raises-4m/| accessdate =21 September 2015}}{{cite news | last=Goldenberg | first=Roy| title =Cyber security co SafeBreach raises $4m| newspaper =[[Globes]]| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =| date =8 July 2015 | url =http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-cyber-security-co-safebreach-raises-4m-1001051356| accessdate =21 September 2015}} Kotler was previously the Security Operation Center Team Leader at [[Tel Aviv]]-based [[Radware]].{{cite news | last=Mills | first=Elinor| title =Using software updates to spread malware| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[CNET]]| date =3 August 2009| url =http://www.cnet.com/news/using-software-updates-to-spread-malware/| accessdate =21 September 2015}} He has given multiple talks at [[DEF CON]], the world's largest [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]] convention.{{cite news | last= | first=| title =קבוצתחוקרים ישראליים מזהירים: תהליך העדכון של תוכנות חשוף להפצת מזיקים | newspaper =| location = | pages = | language =Hebrew | publisher =PC.co| date =3 August 2009| url =http://www.pc.co.il/it-news/14738/?cat=3551| accessdate =21 September 2015}}{{cite news | last=Greene | first=Tim| title =Defcon: VoIP makes a good platform for controlling botnets| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[Network World]]| date =9 August 2011| url =http://www.networkworld.com/article/2180023/uc-voip/defcon--voip-makes-a-good-platform-for-controlling-botnets.html| accessdate =21 September 2015}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sii.org.il/514-he/SII.aspx?committee_number=2114&PageMode=4&committee_name=%D7%90%D7%91%D7%98%D7%97%D7%AA+%D7%9E%D7%99%D7%93%D7%A2\|title=חברים בוועדות תקינה אבטחת מידע|author= |language=Hebrew|website=www.sii.org.il |publisher=[[Standards Institute of Israel]] |accessdate=21 September 2015}} ==Career== Kotler is an [[Autodidacticism|autodidact]] and played with computers and programmed since an early age. He started his career with the [[Israel Defense Forces]].{{cite news | last=Masserini | first=John Lucas| title =SafeBreach Raises $4 million In First Funding Round| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =Security Current| date =8 July 2015| url =http://www.securitycurrent.com/en/news/ac_news/safebreach-raises-4-million-in-first-funding-round| accessdate =21 September 2015}} After serving in the military, Kotler worked at Radware where he became the [[Security operations center|Security Operation Center]] Team Leader.{{cite news | last=Kotler | first=Itzik| title =Web 2.0: Attack of the JavaScript malware| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =''[[SC Magazine]]''| date =30 July 2008| url =http://www.scmagazine.com/web-20-attack-of-the-javascript-malware/article/113132/| accessdate =21 September 2015}} In 2009, Kotler (along with colleague, Tomer Bitton) demonstrated at DEF CON how a hacker could feasibly spread [[malware]] through software updates for applications like [[Skype]]. At the conference, Kotler and Bitton released a tool known as Ippon ("game over" in [[judo]] parlance) that could ask users on a public Wi-Fi network to update a specific application. If the users agreed, they would download malware instead of the updated version of the application. Kotler left Radware in 2010 and joined a digital security firm, Security Art. Kotler served as the company's CTO. In May 2011, Kotler presented at the HackInTheBox conference in [[Amsterdam]] where he demonstrated how a [[Stuxnet]]-like malware could physically destroy servers in a [[Denial-of-service attack#Permanent denial-of-service attacks|permanent denial-of-service (PDoS) attack]].{{cite news | last=Rubens | first=Paul| title =Stop Software Attacks From Destroying Your Servers| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[Serverwatch.com]]| date =30 June 2011| url =http://www.serverwatch.com/tutorials/article.php/3936741/Stop-Software-Attacks-From-Destroying-Your-Servers.htm| accessdate =21 September 2015}} Later in 2011, Kotler and [[Iftach Ian Amit]] presented at DEF CON, demonstrating how a bot master could communicate with [[botnets]] and with "zombie machines" using [[VoIP]] conference calls. Their open-source software, Moshi Moshi, illustrated how they could send instructions to and receive data from botnets and infiltrated networks using any phone line (including payphones).{{cite news | last=Greene | first=Tim| title =10 scariest hacks from Black Hat and Defcon| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher =[[Network World]]| date =10 August 2011| url =http://www.networkworld.com/article/2868939/lan-wan/10-scariest-hacks-from-black-hat-and-defcon.html#slide3| accessdate =21 September 2015}} Kotler also hosted a "Hack-a-thon" in 2011 with the goal of teaching hackers new techniques and improving information security.{{cite news | last= | first=| title =ריצת המרתון של ההאקרים| newspaper =[[Globes]]| location = | pages = | language =Hebrew | publisher =| date =27 June 2011 | url =https://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000658245| accessdate =21 September 2015}} After leaving Security Art, Kotler went on to co-found SafeBreach with Guy Bejerano in September 2014.{{cite news | last= | first=| title =סקויה ושלמה קרמר משקיעים 4 מיליון דולר בחברת אבטחת מידע ישראלית| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language =Hebrew | publisher =[[TheMarker]]| date =8 July 2015 | url =http://www.themarker.com/technation/1.2678804| accessdate =21 September 2015}} Kotler serves as the company's CTO. In July 2015, SafeBreach announced that it had raised $4 million in funding from [[Silicon Valley]]-based [[Sequoia Capital]] and [[angel investor]], [[Shlomo Kramer]]. One of the company's primary services is a simulated "war game" that seeks to find breaches in a network's system. Kotler is the author of "Reverse Engineering with LD_PRELOAD," an article published in 2005.{{cite news|last1=Kotler|first1=Izik|title=Reverse Engineering with LD_PRELOAD|url=https://securityvulns.com/articles/reveng/|accessdate=14 October 2015|publisher=Security Vulns|date=6 July 2005}} The article discussed how [[Dynamic linker|LD_PRELOAD]] can be abused in order to highjack functions and inject code and manipulate applications flow.{{cite book|last1=Ligh|first1=Michael Hale|title=The Art of Memory Forensics: Detecting Malware and Threats in Windows, Linux, and Mac Memory|date=2014|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9781118824993}} The same year, Kotler wrote for and presented at the 22nd [[Chaos Communication Congress]].{{cite web|title=Advanced Buffer Overflow Methods or Smack the Stack|url=https://events.ccc.de/congress/2005/fahrplan/events/491.en.html|website=Chaos Communication Congress|accessdate=14 October 2015}} His presentation "Advanced Buffer Overflow Methods" was used in various academic papers and conferences.{{cite news|last1=Heelan|first1=Sean|title=Automatic Generation of Control Flow Hijacking Exploits for Software Vulnerables|url=http://www.cprover.org/dissertations/thesis-Heelan.pdf|accessdate=14 October 2015|publisher=Univbersity of Oxford|date=3 September 2009}}{{cite news|title=CSE 277 - Computer Security|url=http://cseweb.ucsd.edu/classes/wi12/cse227-a/227wi12Lec2.pdf|accessdate=14 October 2015|publisher=ECSD.edu}}{{cite news|last1=Muller|first1=Tilo|title=ASLR Smack & Laugh Reference|url=https://ece.uwaterloo.ca/~vganesh/TEACHING/S2014/ECE458/aslr.pdf|accessdate=14 October 2015|publisher=Seminar on Advanced Espoitation Techniques|date=17 February 2008}} Additional work includes speaking at BlackHat USA and RSA Europe in 2008 on the topic of a prototype Javascript malware called Jinx,{{cite news|url=http://publishing.yudu.com/Anwgx/RSAConfEuro08Bro/resources/15.htm|title= RSA Conference Europe 2008}}{{cite news|title=Javascript to be next core malware language|url=http://www.itnews.com.au/news/javascript-to-be-next-core-malware-language-126967|accessdate=20 October 2015|publisher=itNews|date=30 October 2008}} and organizing two additional hackathons proving the concept of Trojan in Python that infects Python files.{{cite news|last1=Doherty |first1=Stephen |title=THis Python Has Venom! |url=http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/python-has-venom |accessdate=20 October 2015 |publisher=Symantec |date=7 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206115837/http://www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/python-has-venom |archivedate= 6 December 2011 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://safebreach.com/ SafeBreach Official Website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Kotler, Itzik}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Chief technology officers]] [[Category:Israeli businesspeople]] [[Category:Israeli inventors]] [[Category:Israeli military personnel]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]
