{{Multiple issues| {{advert|date=June 2015}} {{overly detailed|date=June 2015}} }} {{Infobox book | name = Jackass Investing:
Don't do it. Profit from it. | image = Book Cover Image - Jackass Investing.png | caption = | alt = | author = [[Michael Dever]] | title_orig = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | subject = [[Investing]] | genre = | publisher = Ignite LLC | publisher2 = | pub_date = 2011 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = 284 | awards = | isbn = 978-0-9835040-0-9 | oclc = 760086114 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | wikisource = }} '''''Jackass Investing: Don't do it. Profit from it.''''' is a book written by [[Michael Dever]] published by Ignite LLC in 2011. Dever is the founder and CEO of [[Brandywine Asset Management|Brandywine Asset Management, Inc.]], an investment management firm founded in 1982. The book has also been released under the title '''''Exploiting the Myths: Profiting from Wall Street's misguided beliefs.''''' ==Overview== ''"Jackass Investing"'' is a best-selling investment book that challenges conventional investment wisdom and presents an entirely new system of thought. The book describes 20 common investment myths and explains why each is a myth and not a fact. The book is based on the trading philosophy of author [[Michael Dever]]. Dever's trading philosophy is based on broad strategy and market diversification. According to Dever, the definition of "Jackass Investing" is taking unnecessary risk. The book was published in 2011, but Dever initially developed the idea for the book in 1999. He decided to write ''"Jackass Investing"'' to systematically refute major investment myths by presenting the truth. He believes that most investment professionals preach similar "myths" that prohibit investors from creating truly diversified portfolios. Dever introduces the concept of "return drivers" and explains how to use them to create trading strategies, which are the components necessary to create a truly diversified portfolio. A return driver is the core underlying reason that drives the price of a market. ==The Myths== The "myths" include the following: *Myth #1: Stocks Provide an Intrinsic Return *Myth #2: Buy and Hold Works Well for Long Term Investors *Myth #3: You Can't Time the Market *Myth #4: "Passive" Investing Beats "Active" Investing *Myth #5: Stay Invested So You Don't Miss the Best Days *Myth #6: Buy Low, Sell High *Myth #7: It's Bad to Chase Performance *Myth #8: Trading is Gambling - Investing is Safer *Myth #9: Risk Can Be Measured Statistically *Myth #10: Short Selling is Destabilizing and Risky *Myth #11: Commodity Trading is Risky *Myth #12: Futures Trading is Risky *Myth #13: It's Best to Follow Expert Advice *Myth #14: Government Regulations Protect Investors *Myth #15: The Largest Investors Hold All the Cards *Myth #16: Allocate a Small Amount to Foreign Stocks *Myth #17: Lower Risk by Diversifying Across Asset Classes *Myth #18: Diversification Failed in the '08 Financial Crisis *Myth #19: Too Much Diversification Lowers Returns *Myth #20: There is No Free Lunch ==References== {{Reflist| refs= {{cite web|title=Myth: Largest Investors Hold All the Cards|url=http://ai-cio.com/channel/MMEDIA/Myth__Largest_Investors_Hold_All_the_Cards,_Says_Author.aspx|work=ai-CIO.com|publisher=Asset International|date=January 16, 2013}} {{cite web|title=From rural Pennsylvania, Brandywine takes on the world|url=http://www.automatedtrader.net/articles/first-person/137298/from-rural-pennsylvania--brandywine-takes-on-the-world|work=Automated Trader|date=Q4 2012}} {{cite web|title=Philly Deals: 'Jackass' Investing, not quite the Bogle way|url=http://articles.philly.com/2012-07-11/business/32619872_1_mutual-funds-jackass-small-investors|work=Philly.com|date=July 11, 2012}} {{cite web|title=Your Investments: Top fund manager shares some tips|url=http://www.jpost.com/Business/Commentary/Article.aspx?id=246018|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=November 17, 2011}} {{cite web|title=Jackass Investing: Don't do it. Profit from it.|url=http://www.futuresmag.com/2011/07/11/jackass-investing-donrsquot-do-it-profit-from-it|work=Futures Magazine|date=July 11, 2011}} {{cite web|title=Author of "Jackass Investing" employs the multi-strategy systematic model he preaches|url=http://www.opalesque.com/new-managers/5/editorialnewmanagers-may-2012-opalesque-s-emerging.html|work=Opalesque's Emerging Manager Monitor|publisher=Opalesque|date=May 2012}} {{cite journal|title=Getting Along with Your MOM ('Manager of Managers')|journal=Financial Trader|volume=4|issue=5}} }} ==External links== *[http://www.jackassinvesting.com/ Jackass Investing - Official Website] *[http://brandywine.com/ Brandywine Asset Management, Inc.] *[https://twitter.com/MikeDever/ Mike Dever on Twitter] *[http://www.michaelcovel.com/2012/02/14/mike-dever-of-brandywine-the-interview/ "Mike Dever of Brandywine: The Interview" | Michael Covel | The Trend Following Manifesto | February 14, 2012] *[http://jackassinvesting.com/blog/2012/05/05/wall-street-journal-interview/ The Wall Street Journal This Weekend | May 5, 2012] *[https://www.bloomberg.com/video/dever-experts-are-no-better-at-managing-money-ZL7~2qmCRHmw7J_1ltPg1A.html "Dever: Experts Are No Better at Managing Money" | Bloomberg TV | May 31, 2012] *[http://www.michaelcovel.com/2012/07/03/mike-dever-on-the-podcast-for-a-return-visit-new-and-extended/ "Mike Dever on the Podcast for a Return Visit: New and Extended" | Michael Covel | The Trend Following Manifesto | July 3, 2012] *[http://jackassinvesting.com/blog/2012/07/23/mike-dever-featured-on-the-business-tv-show-money-matters/ Mike Dever on "Money Matters" | July 23, 2012] *[https://www.bloomberg.com/video/breaking-down-investing-myths-dDB6sZiETNWyNds4xDNCsg.html "Breaking Down Investing Myths" | Bloomberg TV | July 24, 2012] [[Category:2011 books]] [[Category:Books about traders]] [[Category:Business books]] [[Category:Finance books]]

{{Infobox person | name = Jamila Abbas | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1984}}{{cite web| url=https://www.wired.co.uk/article/mfarm | title=MFarm empowers Kenya's farmers with price transparency and market access |date=21 June 2013 | accessdate=20 December 2017 | first=Olivia |last=Solon |location=London | publisher=[[Wired UK|Wired Magazine UK]]}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater ='''[[Strathmore University]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Science]])}} | occupation = [[Computer Scientist]] & [[Business Executive]] | years_active = 2009 — present | nationality = Kenyan | ethnicity = | citizenship = Kenyan | residence = | known_for = Leadership | networth = | home_town = | title = Founder & [[chief executive officer|COO]] of [https://www.mfarm.co.ke/ MFarm Kenya Limited] | spouse = | religion = }} '''Jamilla Abbas''', is a [[software engineer]], [[businesswoman]] and [[entrepreneur]] in [[Kenya]]. She is the co-founder and [[chief executive officer]] of MFarm Kenya Limited, an internet-based organisation that helps farmers find the best farm implements, seeds, access to weather reports and market information.{{cite web| url=http://www.nu-viz.org/news/jamila-abbas-tech-entrepreneur-to-direct-new-vision-foundation-in-kenya |title=Jamila Abbas, tech entrepreneur, to direct New Vision Foundation | date=5 February 2017 | accessdate=20 December 2017 | publisher=New Vision Organization (NVO) |author=NVO}} ==Background and education== Jamila was born in Kenya and attended local schools for her pre-university education. She attended [[Strathmore University]], graduating with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Software engineering]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/news/Girls-who-created-social-network-for-farmers-/1056-1085706-oxqkwxz/index.html |title=Girls who created social network for farmers |accessdate=20 December 2017 | date=7 January 2011 | newspaper=[[Daily Nation]] |first=John |last=Makeni |location=Nairobi}} ==Career== Following her graduation from Strathmore University, Jamila was hired by [[Kenya Medical Research Institute]] (KEMRI). She also became member at iHub, a technology community, where techies gather to exchange ideas. There, she was reconnected with Susan Oguya, a friend from university. In September 2010, Jamila and Susan decided to actively do something about the plight of Kenyan small-scale farmers, using technology. The two women, also joined ''AkiraChix'', another forum for women with interest in information technology. There, they met three other Strathmore University students, Linda Omwenga, Lillian Nduati, and Catherine Kiguru. The five of them decided to enter IPO48, a software development competition. The event, involved 100 contestants, organised in seventeen teams. The objective was to develop a computer application, which can be turned into a markatable business, all within 48 hours. The competition was organized by ''HumanIPO'', from [[Estonia]]. In November 2011, the five women won the competition, with their M-Farm application, that connects farmers with agro-suppliers, cooperatives and enables them to access current market prices for their produce in a timely manner. The five ladies also won the top prize of KSh1 million (approx. US$10,000). The group used their prize money to incorporate M-Farm Kenya Limited, with Jamila Abbas as [[CEO]], Susan Oguya as [[Chief Operations Officer|COO]]. Linda Omwenga and Catherine Kiguru were marketing officers and Lillian Nduati was the public relations officers. ==Other considerations== Ms. Abbas concurrently serves as the country director of [http://www.nu-viz.org/ New Vision Foundation], a Minneapolis-based non-profit organisation. ==See also== *[[Susan Oguya]] *[[Agriculture in Kenya]] *[[Economy of Kenya]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mfarm.co.ke/ Website of M-Farm Kenya Limited] *[https://nairobigarage.com/startup-mfarm/ Startup: MFarm {{!}} Connecting Farmers] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abbas, Jamila}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kenyan software engineers]] [[Category:Kenyan chief executives]] [[Category:Strathmore University alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan women in business]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]] [[Category:Kenyan women business executives]] [[Category:People from Wajir County]] [[Category:Kenyan women computer scientists]]

{{short description|U.S. Representative from Massachusetts}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2018}} {{GA icon}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Joe Kennedy III |image = Joe Kennedy III, 115th official photo.jpg |state = [[Massachusetts]] |district = {{ushr|MA|4|4th}} |term_start = January 3, 2013 |term_end = |predecessor = [[Barney Frank]] |successor = |birth_name = Joseph Patrick Kennedy III |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1980|10|4}} |birth_place = [[Boston]], Massachusetts, U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = {{marriage|Lauren Birchfield|December 1, 2012}} |children = 2 |parents = [[Joseph P. Kennedy II]] (Father) Sheila Brewster Rauch (Mother) |relatives = ''See [[Kennedy family]]'' |education = [[Stanford University]] ([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])
[[Harvard University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |website = {{url|kennedy.house.gov|House website}} }} '''Joseph Patrick Kennedy III''' (born October 4, 1980), is an American lawyer and politician serving as the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|MA|4}} since 2013. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], his congressional district extends from the western suburbs of [[Boston]] to the state's [[South Coast (Massachusetts)|South Coast]]. A son of former Representative [[Joseph P. Kennedy II]], he worked as a [[Peace Corps]] volunteer and as an assistant district attorney in the [[Cape and Islands]] and [[Middlesex County, Massachusetts]] offices before his election to Congress. Kennedy is a grandson of [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] and former [[United States Attorney General]] [[Robert F. Kennedy|Robert F. "Bobby" Kennedy]], a grand-nephew of President [[John F. Kennedy]] and U.S. Senator [[Ted Kennedy]], and a great-grandson of [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.|Joseph Patrick Kennedy]], former [[United States Ambassador to the United Kingdom|U.S. Ambassador to the United Kingdom]]. His great-grandmother [[Rose Kennedy]] was the daughter of [[John F. Fitzgerald]], a member of the U.S. House of Representatives and Mayor of Boston. Born in [[Brighton, Massachusetts]], Kennedy was raised in the Boston area with his twin brother, Matthew Rauch "Matt" Kennedy. After graduating from [[Stanford University]] he spent two years in the [[Dominican Republic]] as a member of the Peace Corps, and earned his law degree at [[Harvard Law School]] in 2009. He resigned as a prosecutor in early 2012 to run for the seat held by retiring Congressman [[Barney Frank]]. He was sworn into office in January 2013 and sits on the [[U.S. House Committee on Energy and Commerce]]. ==Early life and career== Kennedy was born October 4, 1980{{cite web |url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=K000379 |title=Kennedy, Joseph P. III |work=Biographical Directory of the United States Congress}} in [[Brighton, Boston|Brighton]], a neighborhood of [[Boston]], to Sheila Brewster (Rauch) and [[Joseph P. Kennedy II|Joseph Patrick "Joe" Kennedy II]]. He was born eight minutes after his fraternal twin brother, Matthew. He and Matt are the eldest grandsons of Senator [[Robert F. Kennedy|Robert Francis "Bobby" Kennedy]] and [[Ethel Kennedy|Ethel Skakel]].{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/16/magazine/joe-kennedy-iii.html?pagewanted=all | title = Keeping Up With the Kennedys | author = Edith Zimmerman | work = [[The New York Times]] | date=September 12, 2012}}{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2012/03/18/for_the_kennedy_clan_he_is_generation_next/|work=[[The Boston Globe]] |title=For the Kennedy clan, he is Generation Next |date=March 17, 2012 |author=Jacobs, Sally}} Kennedy was raised in Brighton and in the coastal town of [[Marshfield, Massachusetts|Marshfield]], also spending summers on [[Cape Cod]].{{cite news|url=http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100228/NEWS/2280329/-1/news |title=Not your average Joe (Kennedy) |work=[[Cape Cod Times]] |date=February 28, 2010 |author=Vosk, Stephanie |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130512064256/http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100228%2FNEWS%2F2280329%2F-1%2Fnews |archivedate=May 12, 2013 |df= }} From birth, Kennedy was engulfed in politics; in 1980, his parents were working on the [[Democratic Party presidential primaries, 1980|presidential campaign]] of U.S. Senator [[Ted Kennedy]], the boys' great-uncle. Kennedy's father was elected to Congress in 1986. The pressures of political life strained Joseph and Sheila's marriage, and they divorced in 1991. The twins spent the following years moving between Brighton and Cambridge. [[File:Joseph P Kennedy III in Dominican Republic.png|thumb|left|Kennedy (left) in the Dominican Republic as part of the Peace Corps]] After graduating from the [[Buckingham Browne & Nichols]] School in Cambridge, Kennedy along with his brother enrolled in [[Stanford University]], where he majored in [[management science]] and engineering. Kennedy's reputation as a [[teetotaler]] earned him the college nickname "Milkman", as his teammates on the club [[lacrosse]] team would jokingly order him glasses of milk at bars. While at Stanford, Kennedy roomed with future [[NBA]] player [[Jason Collins]].{{cite news |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/magazine/news/20130429/jason-collins-gay-nba-player |title=Why NBA center Jason Collins is coming out now |date=April 29, 2013 |work=[[Sports Illustrated]]}} After graduating in 2003, Kennedy joined the [[Peace Corps]]; a fluent speaker of Spanish, he worked in the [[Puerto Plata Province|Puerto Plata]] province of the [[Dominican Republic]] from 2004 to 2006, helping local tour guides in the 27 Charcos reserve in the Río Damajagua Park. He reorganized the group with some outside backing, directing the guides to rebuild parts of the park and develop skills to make the operation more attractive to tourists.{{cite web |url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/congress-legacy/massachusetts-4th-house-district-20121101 |work=[[National Journal]] |title=Massachusetts, 4th House District |date=November 6, 2012}} "We basically created a union," said Kennedy, who reported that the group's efforts won higher wages for employees while improving revenue for the tour companies.{{cite news|url=http://www.capecodchronicle.com/harnews/har050709_6.htm |title=Joseph P. Kennedy III Urges Young People To Act Locally, And Globally |author=Pollock, Alan |date=May 7, 2009 |work=The Cape Cod Chronicle |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624153955/http://www.capecodchronicle.com/harnews/har050709_6.htm |archivedate=June 24, 2013 |df= }} According to a press release, his other activities in the Peace Corps included "stints as an Anti-Poverty Consultant for the Office of the President of the [[Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste]] and a Research Analyst for the [[United Nations Development Program]]."{{cite web |url=http://middlesexda.com/news/press-release-archive.php?reference=382 |title=Kennedy Joins Middlesex District Attorney's Office |date=August 24, 2011 |publisher=Office of the Middlesex District Attorney}} ===Entry into law and politics=== [[File:FileJoseph P. Kennedy III 2011 uncropped.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Kennedy speaking at the 50th Anniversary of the [[Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium]] (2011)]] In April 2006, Kennedy returned to Massachusetts, where he and his brother co-chaired Ted Kennedy's [[United States Senate election in Massachusetts, 2006|re-election campaign]]. That fall, Kennedy enrolled in [[Harvard Law School]]. While in school, Kennedy worked for the [[Harvard Legal Aid Bureau]], providing legal aid to low-income tenants with foreclosure cases in the wake of the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008|2008 financial crisis]]. As he was a prosecutor, Kennedy worked as a technical editor for the ''Harvard Human Rights Journal'', on a staff with his classmate and future wife, Lauren Anne Birchfield. In 2007 he and Birchfield co-founded ''Picture This: Justice and Power'', an after-school program for youths in Boston's [[Jamaica Plain]] neighborhood.{{cite news|title=Joseph Kennedy III joins Middlesex DA's Office|url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/news/x1153512415/Joseph-Kennedy-III-joins-Middlesex-DAs-Office |deadurl=yes|accessdate=April 12, 2013|newspaper=[[The MetroWest Daily News]]|date=August 24, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412074131/http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/news/x1153512415/Joseph-Kennedy-III-joins-Middlesex-DAs-Office|archivedate=April 12, 2013}}{{cite news |url=http://www.law.harvard.edu/news/spotlight/alumni-pursuits/related/joe_kennedy_iii_election.html |title=The Next Generation |work=Alumni Pursuits |publisher=[[Harvard Law School]] |year=2012 |author=Newburger, Emily}} He began an internship at the [[Cape and Islands]] [[District Attorney]]'s Office in 2008. After receiving his [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] degree from Harvard Law School in 2009, Kennedy was hired at the Cape and Islands Office as an assistant district attorney (DA). He considered running for the Cape-based U.S. House seat held by retiring Rep. [[Bill Delahunt]] in early 2010, but decided against it.{{cite news|url=http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100301/NEWS/3010311 |title=Joseph Kennedy III says he won't seek seat |work=Cape Cod Times |author=Vosk, Stephanie |date=March 1, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115005518/http://www.capecodonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100301%2FNEWS%2F3010311 |archivedate=January 15, 2012 |df= }} In September 2011, he joined the Middlesex County District Attorney's Office, also as an assistant DA.{{cite web | url=http://middlesexda.com/news/press-release.php?reference=382 | title = Middlesex District Attorney | publisher = Middlesexda.com |author = Jessica Venezia Pastore & Stephanie Chelf Guyotte | date= August 24, 2011 | accessdate = January 28, 2012}} He resigned several months later, in preparation for the announcement that he would seek political office.{{cite news|author=Walker, Adrian |url=http://www.boston.com/2012/01/05/joek/tFAemLmqix0uZ61FajdjfM/story.html?comments=all | title = Joseph P. Kennedy III, Family Scion, Explores Run for Barney Frank's House Seat | publisher= [[Boston.com]] | date= January 5, 2012 |accessdate= February 28, 2012}} == U.S. House of Representatives == === Elections === ==== 2012 ==== [[File:Joe Kennedy, Official Portrait, 113th Congress.jpg|thumb|right|Official portrait of Joe Kennedy as U.S. Representative in 2012]] {{See also|Massachusetts's 4th congressional district election, 2012}} In January 2012, Kennedy announced he would form an exploratory committee to run in the newly redrawn [[Massachusetts's 4th congressional district|4th congressional district of Massachusetts]]. Congressman [[Barney Frank]], who had previously represented the district, had announced his retirement, leaving an open field for the seat.{{cite web|author= Clift, Eleanor |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/02/17/joe-kennedy-iii-takes-the-torch-from-retiring-barney-frank.html |title=Joe Kennedy III Takes the Torch from Retiring Barney Frank |work= [[The Daily Beast]] |date= February 17, 2012 |accessdate= February 28, 2012}} Kennedy explained, "I will then begin to reach out to the people of the Fourth District in order to hear directly from them about the challenges they are facing and their ideas on how we can restore fairness to our system. I will make a final decision about entering the race in the weeks thereafter."{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/politics/30140960/detail.html#ixzz1kXHYizvU |title=Joe Kennedy III Exploring Campaign Run |publisher=[[The Boston Channel]] |date=January 5, 2012 |accessdate=February 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111162652/http://www.thebostonchannel.com/politics/30140960/detail.html#ixzz1kXHYizvU |archivedate=January 11, 2012 }}{{cite news|author= Miga, Andrew |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/01/05/joe-kennedy-run-for-congress-barney-franks-seat_n_1186095.html |title=Joseph Kennedy III Takes Steps Toward A Run For Congress | work = [[The Huffington Post]] |date= January 5, 2012|accessdate= February 28, 2012}} [[File:Joe Kennedy III, Elizabeth Warren, Barney Frank.jpg|thumb|left|Kennedy (l–r) campaigning with [[Elizabeth Warren]] and his predecessor [[Barney Frank]] in 2012]] Kennedy officially entered the election in February 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2012/02/15/ap_source_joe_kennedy_iii_announcing_congress_bid_1329339493/ |title = Joseph Kennedy III Announcing Mass. Congress Bid |publisher=[[Boston.com]] |date = February 15, 2012 |accessdate= February 28, 2012 |first=Steve |last=LeBlanc}} In an announcement video, Kennedy declared, "I believe this country was founded on a simple idea: that every person deserves to be treated fairly, by each other and by their government."{{cite web | author = joekennedy2012 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b7F7MnMdtDw | title = I'm Running | publisher = [[YouTube]] |date = February 15, 2012 | accessdate = February 28, 2012}} In the same video, Kennedy vowed to fight for a "fair job plan", a "better educational system", a "fair tax code" and a "fair housing policy". While several Democratic candidates had prepared to enter the race, the field nearly cleared once Kennedy announced his candidacy. His family roots made him the overwhelming favorite among Massachusetts Democrats.{{cite news |url=http://www.rollcall.com/issues/57_83/joseph_kennedy_iii_4th_district_clears_massachusetts-211730-1.html |title=4th District Field Clears for Joseph Kennedy III in Massachusetts |work=Roll Call |publisher=[[Congressional Quarterly|CQ]] |date=January 24, 2012 |author=Miller, Joshua}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/opinion/editorials/2012/09/01/congressional-district-joe-kennedy-iii-for-democrats/hMDtGqN9FZ85ZoPpUVPmRK/story.html |title=2012 Primary Endorsement: 4th Congressional District: Joe Kennedy III for Democrats |date=September 2, 2012 |work=[[The Boston Globe]]}} In the September 6 primary, he faced Rachel Brown, a [[Lyndon LaRouche]] acolyte; and Herb Robinson, an engineer and musician, winning the primary with 90 percent of the vote.{{cite web |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2012/09/06/bielat-kennedy-vie-for-open-house-seat-neal-keating-defeat-challengers/A7tAMApX6GgtQjtjXTAQFK/story.html |title=Bielat, Kennedy to vie for open House seat |date=September 7, 2012 |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |author=Levenson, Michael}}{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/news/special/politics/2012/state-primary/us-house-district-4.html |title=U.S. House - 4th District - 2012 Primary Results - Massachusetts |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=September 6, 2012}} In the general election campaign he faced Republican nominee [[Sean Bielat]], a technology executive and member of the [[United States Marine Corps Reserve|U.S. Marine Corps Reserve]]. Bielat had run an unsuccessful campaign against Barney Frank in the [[United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts, 2010|2010 election]] for the 4th district seat. In a series of debates, Bielat challenged Kennedy's qualifications for Congress, saying that the Democrat's campaign was coasting on name recognition rather than experience, and that he would be a [[party-line vote]]. Kennedy tried to tie Bielat to the [[The Path to Prosperity|budget platform]] of U.S. Representative [[Paul Ryan]], although Bielat responded that he only supported parts of the plan.{{cite news |url=http://bostonherald.com/news_opinion/us_politics/2012/10/joe_kennedy_iii_sean_bielat_trade_jabs |title=Joe Kennedy III, Sean Bielat trade jabs |author=Stout, Matt |work=[[The Boston Herald]] |date=October 11, 2012}}{{cite news|url=http://www.wbur.org/2012/10/16/bielat-kennedy-final-debate|title=Bielat, Kennedy Meet In Final 4th District Debate|work=[[WBUR News]] |author=Bever, Fred |date=October 16, 2012}} Kennedy raised over $4 million in support of his campaign, far exceeding Bielat's draw of around $900,000.{{cite news |url=http://www.boston.com/metrodesk/2012/11/06/kennedy-takes-fourth-congressional-seat-decisive-win-over-bielat/60L5XbooNio2EJbN63nmiO/story.html |title=Kennedy takes Fourth District congressional seat in decisive win over Bielat |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |author=Arsenault, Mark |date=November 9, 2012}} Kennedy won the November 6 election with 61 percent of the vote to Bielat's 36 percent.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/election/2012/results/state/MA/house |title=Races and Results: U.S. House (Massachusetts) |work=[[CNN]] Election Center |year=2012}} ==== 2014 ==== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts, 2014}} In the 2014 election Joseph P. Kennedy III ran unopposed in the primary election and in the general election. On November 4, 2014, Kennedy was re-elected, winning a second term with 184,158 votes or 97.91%.{{cite web|url=http://www.realclearpolitics.com/elections/live_results/2014/house|title=House election results|publisher=Real Clear Politics|accessdate=November 4, 2014}} ==== 2016 ==== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts, 2016}} In 2016, after running unopposed in the Democratic primary, Kennedy was re-elected to a third term, defeating Republican David Rosa by a margin of more than 40 percentage points.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/elections/results/massachusetts-house-district-4-kennedy-rosa|title=Massachusetts 4th District Results|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=November 16, 2016}} On November 6, 2016, Kennedy was re-elected, winning a 3rd term with 265,823 votes or 70.10% ==== 2018 ==== {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Massachusetts, 2018}} Kennedy was mentioned as a potential candidate for the [[Massachusetts gubernatorial election, 2018|2018 Massachusetts gubernatorial election]]{{cite news |last=Salsberg |first=Bob |url=https://www.boston.com/news/politics/2016/11/28/pivoting-toward-2018-massachusetts-dems-eye-charlie-baker-challenge |title=Pivoting toward 2018, Massachusetts Dems eye Charlie Baker challenge |work=[[Boston.com]] |date=November 28, 2016 |accessdate=February 27, 2017 }} but declined, stating that he did not have plans to run for another office.{{cite web|last1=Metzger|first1=Andy|title=Kennedy says he will seek re-election in 2018|url=http://www.heraldnews.com/news/20170118/kennedy-says-he-will-seek-re-election-in-2018|website=The Herald News|accessdate=March 9, 2017|language=en}} === Tenure === {{U.S. Congress committee assignments |congress = 115 |ref = {{cite web |url=http://www.rollcall.com/members/46526.html |title=Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy III (D-Mass) |work=Roll Call |publisher=[[Congressional Quarterly|CQ]]}} |committees = *'''[[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|Energy and Commerce]]''' **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade|Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade]] **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Health|Health]] **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations|Oversight and Investigations]] }} Kennedy was sworn into the [[113th United States Congress|113th U.S. Congress]] on January 3, 2013, and was assigned to the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|Committee on Foreign Affairs]] and the [[United States House Committee on Science, Space and Technology|Committee on Science, Space and Technology]]. He praised the technology committee assignment as an opportunity to secure federal funding, including [[National Science Foundation]] and [[Small Business Innovation Research]] grants, for life sciences companies in his district. As a freshman in his party, he was unable to secure a seat on the [[United States House Committee on Education and the Workforce|Education Committee]] which he had sought.{{cite news |title=Kennedy named to two House committees |url=http://www.boston.com/politicalintelligence/2013/01/04/joseph-kennedy-named-house-science-and-technology-and-foreign-affairs-committees/reYGrh482OHxYI7vKvrIAK/story.html |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |author=Jan, Tracy |date=January 5, 2013}} [[File:Joe Kennedy Meets With Constituent on Capital Steps.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Kennedy meets with a constituent in Washington, D.C.|Kennedy meets with a constituent in Washington, D.C.]] During a February science committee hearing, he questioned [[Texas Instruments]] president Richard Templeton regarding the company's efforts to compensate cancer-stricken former employees of its [[Attleboro, Massachusetts]], nuclear facility.{{cite news |url=http://www.tauntongazette.com/topstories/x206923381/Kennedy-grills-Texas-Instruments-president |title=Kennedy grills Texas Instruments president |date=February 6, 2013 |author=Nichols, Christopher |work=Taunton Gazette}}{{cite news |url=http://www.thesunchronicle.com/news/local_news/kennedy-questions-ti-president-about-cancer-cases/article_9b76c27c-7096-11e2-9bc6-0019bb2963f4.html |title=Kennedy questions TI president about cancer cases |work=The Sun Chronicle |date=February 6, 2013 |author=Foster, Rick}} A prolific fundraiser, he launched his [[political action committee]], the 4MA PAC, in April.{{cite news |title=Tierney tops state delegation in first quarter fundraising |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2013/04/17/tierney-tops-massachusetts-house-delegation-first-quarter-fundraising/W7slpM42rnsE9x8yrHAgAM/story.html |author=Tracy, Jan |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=April 17, 2013}}{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/post-politics/wp/2013/04/12/rep-joe-kennedy-iii-launches-political-action-committee/ |title=Rep. Joe Kennedy III launches political action committee |date=April 12, 2013 |author=Blake, Aaron |work=Post Politics (The Washington Post)}} As a member of the Foreign Affairs Committee, he traveled in May with four other legislators to [[Afghanistan]], where they met with President [[Hamid Karzai]] and members of the military.{{cite news |title=Kennedy impressed by US efforts to prepare Afghans |work=The Boston Globe |author=Bender, Bryan |date=May 28, 2013 |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2013/05/28/obama-and-christie-reunite-view-recovery-jersey-shore/Gp9jgxVyPm8W2O4q5ZiOWP/story.html}} That month he was named chairman of Governor [[Deval Patrick]]'s [[STEM fields|STEM]] Advisory Council.{{cite news |url=http://www.mass.gov/governor/pressoffice/pressreleases/2013/0529-congressman-kennedy-to-chair-stem-council.html |date=May 29, 2013 |title=Lieutenant Governor Murray announces Congressman Kennedy to lead the governor's STEM Advisory Council |author=Massachusetts Governor's Office}} On July 24, 2013, Kennedy was one of seven members of the [[Congressional Progressive Caucus]]{{cite web|title=Caucus Members|author=|url=https://cpc-grijalva.house.gov/index.cfm?sectionid=71§iontree=2,71|format=|publisher=Congressional Progressive Caucus|date=|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} (CPC) who voted against the Amash-Conyers amendment to limit Section 215 of the [[Patriot Act]], which tried to restrict [[NSA]] surveillance programs. In contrast, a majority of both CPC members and of Democratic members of Congress voted for the amendment, while Kennedy stood out as a supporter of the party leadership. His vote has been criticized as a sign for a lack of commitment to civil liberties.{{cite news |url=http://inthesetimes.com/article/15361/why_did_83_democrats_vote_to_continue_nsa_surveillance/ |date=July 26, 2013 |title=Why Did 83 Democrats Vote to Continue NSA Surveillance? |author=[[In These Times]]}} On January 26, 2018, House Minority Leader [[Nancy Pelosi]] and Senate Minority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] announced he would deliver the Democratic response to President Donald Trump's 2018 State of the Union address.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/rep-joe-kennedy-iii-to-deliver-democratic-response-to-state-of-the-union/|title=Rep. Joe Kennedy III to deliver Democratic response to State of the Union|access-date=January 26, 2018|language=en}}{{cite news|title=Can Joe Kennedy Beat the State of the Union Curse?|url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2018/01/28/kennedy-state-of-the-union-response-rebuttal-curse-216542|accessdate=January 29, 2018|work=POLITICO Magazine}} The selection of Kennedy to give the Democratic response came after criticism that the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] relied too heavily on its oldest leaders since the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]]. In choosing Kennedy, the party is trying to bridge the gap with a new face attached to [[Kennedy family|one of the most famous names in American politics]].{{cite web |last1=Malone |first1=Scott |title=In step to national stage, a young Kennedy to rebut Trump address |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-usa-trump-speech-response/in-step-to-national-stage-a-young-kennedy-to-rebut-trump-address-idUKKBN1FF0G1 |accessdate=January 26, 2018 |agency=Reuters |date=January 25, 2018 |location=Boston |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180126164918/https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-usa-trump-speech-response/in-step-to-national-stage-a-young-kennedy-to-rebut-trump-address-idUKKBN1FF0G1 |archivedate=January 26, 2018 }} He addressed the television cameras and a live studio audience in the automotive body shop of [[Diman Regional Vocational Technical High School]] at [[Fall River, Massachusetts|Fall River]], [[Massachusetts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldnews.com/news/20180130/rep-kennedy-highlights-fall-rivers-resilience-work-ethic-in-rebuttal-to-president-trump|title=Rep. Kennedy highlighted Fall River’s resilience and work ethic in rebuttal to President Trump|work=Herald News, Massachusetts|date=February 1, 2018|accessdate=February 3, 2018}} He is the second member of his family to give the Democratic response, after his great uncle [[Ted Kennedy]] replied to the [[1982 State of the Union Address]].{{cite web|title=Democrat Joe Kennedy to respond to Trump's union speech|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42830963|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=January 27, 2018|date=January 26, 2018}} During his response to the 2018 State of the Union, he praised Black Lives Matter and spoke in Spanish with regards to [[Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals|children who were brought into the United States illegally when they were minors]].{{cite web|title=Joseph P. Kennedy III Gives Democratic Response to State of the Union|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/30/us/joseph-kennedy-democratic-response.html}} ==Personal life== Kennedy married health policy lawyer{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpartnership.org/about-us/staff/lauren-birchfield-kennedy.html |title=Lauren Birchfield Kennedy |publisher=Nationalpartnership.org |date= |accessdate=May 27, 2017}} Lauren Anne Birchfield (born September 21, 1984){{cite web|url=http://www.ourfamtree.org/browse.php/Lauren-Anne-Birchfield/p457445 |title=Joseph Patrick Kennedy + Lauren Anne Birchfield - Our Family Tree |publisher=Ourfamtree.org |date=December 29, 2015 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}} in [[Corona del Mar, California]], on December 1, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/id/50057691/site/todayshow/ns/today-weddings/ |title=Congressman-elect Joe Kennedy III is married|date=December 3, 2012|author=Scott Stump|work=[[MSNBC]]}} The couple met in a Harvard Law School class taught by future senator [[Elizabeth Warren]].{{cite web|url=http://blogs.wpri.com/2013/01/03/joe-kennedy-iii-met-his-wife-in-warrens-harvard-law-class/|title=Joe Kennedy III met his wife in Warren’s Harvard Law class |date=January 3, 2012|accessdate= January 7, 2013|author=Ted Nesi|work=[[WPRI-TV]]}} On December 29, 2015, Birchfield gave birth to their daughter, Eleanor "Ellie" Kennedy.{{cite web|author=Katie McLeod |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/names/2015/12/29/joe-kennedy-iii-announces-birth-daughter-twitter/TfGxiI5hWj8PawStD1p3IL/story.html |title=Joe Kennedy III announces birth of daughter on Twitter |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=December 29, 2015 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}} On December 20, 2017, Kennedy announced the birth of their second child, son James Matthew Kennedy.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/RepJoeKennedy/status/943651631698243584/|title=Meet James Matthew Kennedy. Born early this morning and doing great. First gift he received was (appropriately) a Patriots jersey from Grandpa Joe. Thanks to all for the kind words. We are exhausted, over the moon and deeply grateful!|date=December 20, 2017|accessdate= December 20, 2017}} The family lives in [[Newton, Massachusetts]].https://www.bostonglobe.com/metro/2018/01/30/things-know-about-joseph-kennedy-iii/fI0j0Z8zGmeUdFaBU4UxzO/story.html An heir to [[Joseph P. Kennedy Sr.|Joe Kennedy]]'s fortune, he holds substantial investments in trusts and is estimated to be worth between $20 million and $60 million.{{Cite news|url=https://heavy.com/news/2018/01/joe-kennedy-iii-net-worth/|title=Joe Kennedy’s Net Worth: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|last=Dwilson|first=Stephanie Dube|date=2018-01-30|work=Heavy.com|access-date=2018-08-13|language=en-US}} On [[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]] talk show in April 4, 2018, he stated that [[Markwayne Mullin]] was his best Republican friend.{{cn|date=December 2018}} ==See also== *[[Kennedy family#Kennedy family tree|Kennedy family tree]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://kennedy.house.gov/ Congressman Joe Kennedy] official U.S. House website * [http://joekennedy2012.com/ Joe Kennedy for Congress] * {{Dmoz|Regional/North_America/United_States/Massachusetts/Government/Federal/US_House_of_Representatives/Joseph_P._Kennedy_III_%5BD-4%5D}} * {{CongLinks|fec=H2MA04073|congress=joseph-kennedy/2172}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{s-bef|before=[[Barney Frank]]}} {{s-ttl|title=Member of the [[List of United States Representatives from Massachusetts|U.S. House of Representatives]]

Ethnicity should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Entrepreneur]] | years_active = | era = | employer = | organization = | known_for = | home_town = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Swedish People's Party of Finland|SFP]]<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I">{{cite web |url=http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/kb/artikkeli/5757/ |title=Wickström, John (1870–1959) |last=Hoffman |first=Kai |date=2015-10-23 |website=Kansallisbiografia |publisher=Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seura |location=Helsinki |language=Finnish |access-date=2016-04-14 |registration=yes }}</ref><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II">{{cite web |url=http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/talousvaikuttajat/?iid=407 |title=Teollisuusneuvos John Wickström (1870–1959) |last=Hoffman |first=Kai |date=2012-09-03 |website=Kansallisbiografia |publisher=Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seura |location=Helsinki |language=Finnish |access-date=2016-04-14 |registration=yes}}</ref> | movement = | opponents = | boards = Rakennus Oy Tekno<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/> | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source; do not add a religious denomination here --> | spouse = {{plain list| * 1892–1919: Ida Maria [[née]] Östman (1873–1952) * 1919–death: Julia Wilhelmina née Bergsten (1885–1973) }} | children = {{plain list| * Sigrid Ingeborg (b. 1893) * Werner Theodor (1897–1997) * Roy John Elias (1901–81) * Alma Ellida (b. 1902) * Ingrid Brita Maria, married Sellberg, later Nordling (b. 1920) * Johannes Carl-Gustav (1922–2013) }} | parents = {{plain list| * Johan Mickelsson Wickström * Brita-Lisa née West }} | relatives = | awards = Industrial counsellor (1936)<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/> | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = }}
'''John Wickström''' (until ca. 1889 '''Johannes Wickström'''; 13 December 1870—7 June 1959) was a [[Swedish-speaking population of Finland|Finnish-Swede]] [[engineer]] and [[entrepreneur]].
Wickström was born in [[Kvevlax]], Ostrobothnia. He emigrated to the United States at age of 19 and settled in Chicago, where he studied engineering. Wickström specialised on [[Internal combustion engine|combustion engines]] and founded company for automobile production, but, eventually, his interest focused on [[Inboard motor|boat engines]].
Wickström returned to Finland in 1906 and founded a boat engine factory together with his brother Jakob. The engines became reputable and sales grew until the 1950s, when imported [[outboard engine]]s started to replace the heavy middle engines.
Wickström was married twice.
== Early life == Wickström was born as '''Johannes Wickström''' in Vassor village, [[Kvevlax]], Ostrobothnia. His father Johan Wickström was a [[coppersmith]], manufacturer and painter. The family had nine children, the oldest of which died at a young age. He attended primary school in his home village, but, from a young age, he worked in his father's workshop. He was interested at testing and creating; after seeing a picture of a [[bicycle]] on a [[Sweden|Swedish]] newspaper, he built one for himself.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
== Emigration to America == As many other Ostrobothnians at the time, Johannes became interested in emigrating to the United States. After completing his school and [[confirmation]], he borrowed money from his uncle for travelling over the Atlantic and left Finland in 1889. In the United States, he changed his name to John. Typical to [[Finnish Americans|Finnish immigrants]], he became employed in a mine, but, due to his metalworking skills, he soon got a job in a plumbing company, after which he moved to a Chicago engineering company that produced pumps for pumping water inside skyscrapers. The company tested combustion engines, which were still undeveloped. Wickström studied [[mechanical engineering]] in [[North Park College]], Chicago and was awarded some patents related to engines. Wickström's two younger brothers Mickel and Jakob moved to Chicago as well.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
[[File:Caloric.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Wickström with his family driving his 1898 Caloric car in Chicago in 1899.]] [[File:Caloric II.JPG|200px|thumb|left|John and Jakob Wickström and 1901 introduced Caloric II.]] Soon, Wickström focused solely on combustion engines and founded Chicago Motor Cycle Coach Co. for automobile production in 1898. The first car, branded the Caloric, was produced in the same year. Caloric featured a 10–12-[[Horsepower|hp]] [[petrol engine]], and it gained attention on streets of Chicago.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/> The car was further developed and at the early 20th century an upgraded Caloric II was introduced. Reportedly, Caloric was displayed in the first Chicago Automobile Exhibit in 1901.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström">{{cite journal |last1=Immonen |first1=Mari |year=2016 |title=Moottorikuningas John Wickström |trans-title=Engine king John Wickström |journal=Suomen Historia |language=Finnish |location=Vaasa |publisher=Viipalemediat Oy |issue=2./2016 |pages=60–67 |issn=2342-7981 }}</ref> However, less than ten Caloric cars are known to be produced.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/><ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>
Wickström kept his focus on boat engine production. He ran the Chicago Caloric Engine Company with his business partners. The company built boat engines and repaired cars in its premises located on Wabash Avenue. The boat engines were used at lakes [[Lake Michigan|Michigan]] and [[Lake Superior|Superior]].<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/> Wickström was involved in a third company called Economy Engine Company.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
== Return to Finland == Wickström had difficulties finding financing for engine development; he had to focus the production on existing, although still profitable, models. By using the property he had collected during his stay in the United States, Wickström believed he would be able to continue development of fishing boat engines in Finland, which was still an untapped market.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
Upon returning to Finland in 1906, Wickström had to create a market for his engines. Ostrobothnian fishermen, used to propelling themselves by rowing or sailing over many generations, were wary of combustion engines. In order to convince the potential clientele about the benefits of engine power, Wickström arranged an American-style show event in which he tugged two boats loaded with people by a motor boat up along the [[Kyrönjoki]] River. Despite the excessive load, the travelling took less than one third the time compared to rowing. Consequently, Wickström's engines gained a lot of attention and the demand grew high enough that Wickström could start serial production.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
== Wickström engine production == Wickström founded a boat engine factory in [[Palosaari]], [[Vaasa]] together with his brother Jakob who also returned from America; the third emigrated brother Mickel stayed permanently in the United States. The factory was opened in autumn 1906, and, in addition to boat engines, the company produced [[stationary engine]]s for Finnish farmers to power [[Threshing machine|threshers]] and other machinery. Production of Wickström-engines grew over time and, in 1910, the brothers opened a new facility in [[Vaskiluoto]], close to Vaasa harbour. The company name became Bröderna Wickströms Motorfabrik Ab in [[Swedish language|Swedish]] and Wickström-Veljesten Moottoritehdas Oy in [[Finnish language|Finnish]] ("Wickström Brothers' Engine Works Ltd.").<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/> At the beginning, the brothers produced Caloric engines based on drawings which they had brought with them from America. As the engines turned out to be too complex and unreliable, the company developed modern [[Four-stroke engine|four-stroke]] [[Kerosene|paraffin]] engines, which replaced the older portfolio.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>
{{Reduced pull quote|right|Perdition will come, if our Lord or Wickström's engine won't help.|Fishermen's saying.|<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>}} Wickström engines changed the fishermen's way of living drastically. Due to their higher speed, the fishermen could travel home every evening, instead of bunking in fishing lodges. In 1912, 150 Ostrobothnian fishing boats featured engines. Among Finnish fishermen, Wickström's products reached a reputation of ultimately reliable power units.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>
[[File:Wickström engine brochure 1933.jpg|200px|thumb|Wickström engine brochure from 1933.]] After the modest start, demand grew especially after World War I, and the facilities were enlarged several times. In the 1930s, the annual production was about 1,000 units,<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/> and the portfolio consisted of a number of marine and stationary engine models. The company bought production licences for British [[R A Lister and Company|Lister]] diesel engines.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/> At the turn of the 1950s, the headcount reached almost 200, and the company produced thousands of engines per year. By that time, few other engine producers had started production in Vaasa, and the city became the centre of the Finnish small engine production. Wickström was the leading producer of small engines, and any other boat engine brands were an exception in the area.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/> As demand of stationary engines decreased after World War II, the company focused exclusively on boat engines. Wickström engines were exported to Sweden, Norway, Iceland, Japan and Canada.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>
The Wickström Brothers' Engine Works had a good reputation as an employer, and workers typically made long careers in the factory. Wickström led the company until the end of his life, and he was an appreciated manager.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/> He believed that the robust middle engines, which the company produced, would stay competitive on the market; he considered outboard engines to be rubbish and did not believe in their future. However, as light glass fibre boats pushed aside the heavy wooden boats, American and Swedish produced outboard engines replaced the middle engines over time.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/> After Wickström's death in 1959, the company kept existing for a couple of decades. By then, the Wickström company had lost the spirit of innovation, although the main reason for its decline was the spread of outboard engines and subsequent disappearing of its market.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
== Personal life == Wickström married Ida Maria née Östman (1873–1952) in 1892. Their children were Sigrid Ingeborg (b. 1893), Werner Theodor (b. 1897), Roy John Elias (b. 1901) and Alma Ellida (b. 1902). The couple was divorced in 1919;<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/> as divorcing was rare and generally not socially accepted at the time, a possible reason could have been rumours about Wickström's illegitimate son in the United States.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/> In the same year, Wickström married Julia Wilhelmina née Bergsten, with whom he had Ingrid Brita Maria (b. 1920) and Johannes Carl-Gustav (b. 1922).<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/>
At an early age, Wickström committed to total abstinence from alcohol, and he took part in [[temperance society]] activities.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/> In Chicago, he was a member of the local Swedish–Finnish temperance society (Svensk-Finska Nykterhetsföreningen Topelius), and he was chairman of the Swedish–Finnish Temperance Federation (Svensk-Finska Nykterhetsförbundet).<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/> In Finland, Wickström supported prohibition.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>
Wickström was a founding member of the Finnish [[Odd Fellows]] fraternity in 1925. He was member of the Vaasa city council.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
Wickström financed his birth municipality Kvevlax, his former school in Vassor village and craft school Kvevlax Slöjdskola. Many craft school students were inspired by Wickström's example, becoming entrepreneurs themselves.<ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström I"/><ref name="Biografiakeskus: John Wickström II"/>
== Legacy == The Vaasa City Theatre presented a play about Wickström's life. The performance, written by [[Antti Tuuri]] and directed by [[Erik Kiviniemi]], had its premiere in autumn 2015. [[Jorma Tommila]] starred in the main role.<ref name="Suomen Historia: John Wickström"/>

{{Infobox company | name = KRP Properties | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1986 | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Kanata, Ontario|Kanata]], [[Ontario]] | location_country = [[Canada]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = Commercial real estate | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = [[Wesley Clover]] | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.krpproperties.com/ www.krpproperties.com] | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''KRP Properties''' (formerly Kanata Research Park Corporation) is a Canadian real estate corporation in [[Kanata, Ontario|Kanata]], [[Ontario]], Canada, which leases and develops commercial [[real estate]].<ref name="Bloomberg">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=10220579 |title=KRP Properties LLC: Private Company Information |website=Bloomberg |access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref> It operates the [[business park]]s known as Kanata Research Park and Kanata North Technology Park.<ref name="KRP Parks">{{Cite web |url=https://www.krpproperties.com/the-parks/ |title=The Parks |website=KRP Properties |access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref>
The parks are home to many companies, mostly [[Information Technology|IT]]-related, such as [[Mitel]], [[Ericsson]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.obj.ca/Technology/2011-06-28/article-2617590/UPDATE%3A-Ericsson-to-move-to-Kanata-Research-Park-in-2012/1 |title=UPDATE: Ericsson to move to KRP Properties in 2012 |publisher=[[Ottawa Business Journal]] |date=June 28, 2011 |accessdate=June 26, 2015}}</ref> March Networks, [[Huawei]], [[Hewlett-Packard]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.obj.ca/Other/Special-Reports/2010-12-02/article-2011223/Kanata-Research-Park%3A-Employees-Choice-Awards/1 |title=Kanata Research Park: Employees' Choice Awards |publisher=[[Ottawa Business Journal]] |date=December 2, 2010 |accessdate=June 26, 2015}}</ref> [[Amdocs]], [[DragonWave]], [[Solace Corporation|Solace]], [[Pleora|Pleora Technologies]], [[Protecode]], [[TSMC]] Design Technology Canada, [[Halogen Software]] and [[Nokia]]. There are also [[Ciena]] and [[Cisco]] locations in the area. It is also home to the [[Brookstreet Hotel]] and the [[Marshes Golf Club]].
As of 2018, Martin Vandewouw is president of KRP Properties. The supporting management team includes Linda A.Sprung (Director of Leasing), Terry Young (Director of Property Management), Richard Goldstein (Director of Construction), Monique Clayton (Director of Finance) and J.Patrick Ferris (General Counsel and Corporate Secretary).<ref name="Bloomberg"/><ref name="KRP Team">{{Cite web |url=https://www.krpproperties.com/krp-difference/#team |title=KRP Difference - Management Team |website=KRP Properties |access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref>
In 2015, KRP Properties was selected for the Sustainability Award at the 2015 Ottawa Business Awards. They were selected because of their efforts towards integrating energy and waste reduction, water conservation, green cleaning and sustainable purchasing into all aspects of their business operations.<ref name= awards >{{citenews | url=http://www.obj.ca/Other/Special-Reports/2015-11-27/article-4358128/Best-Ottawa-Business-Awards---Performance-Award-winners/1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202003953/http://www.obj.ca/Other/Special-Reports/2015-11-27/article-4358128/Best-Ottawa-Business-Awards---Performance-Award-winners/1 |archive-date=2 February 2017 |title=Ottawa Business Awards Performance Award Winners | newspaper=Ottawa Business Journal | date=September 27, 2015 | accessdate= January 18, 2017}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Dr. Reginald Boulos | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Reginald Pierre Boulos | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1956}} | alma_mater = [[Haitian Medical Faculty]]
[[Tulane University]] | occupation = {{nowrap|Chairman & CEO of Boulos Investment Group}} [[Investor]] | website = | footnotes = | signature = }} '''Reginald Boulos''' (born 1956) is a former President of the National Chamber of Commerce and Industry of [[Haiti]], a third generation [[Lebanon|Lebanese]]-Haitian, medical doctor, an entrepreneur and businessman, and philanthropist.http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-fairbanks/haitians-dont-deserve-our_b_539841.html ==Early life and education== Reginald Boulos was born in 1956, son of Carlos and Aimee (née Abraham) Boulos. Dr. Boulos and is one of 6 children (Frantz Boulos, Kathleen Boulos Weckering, Senator Rudolph Boulos, Marie Boulos, Dr. Carlo Boulos). Along with his brother Dr. Carlo Boulos, they attended and earned a medical degree in 1981 from the Port-au-Prince School of Medicine in Haiti. Reginald then furthered his education by graduating in 1982 with a Master of Public Health and Tropical Medicine at the [[Tulane University]] [[Tulane University School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine|School of Public Health]] in [[New Orleans]]. He conducted research with an associate professor at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. He also holds certification from the [[MIT Sloan School of Management]] for senior executives. ==Business endeavors== {{BLP unsourced section|date=June 2011}} In 1996, Dr. Boulos left the medical practice to start a new career in business development. While representing his family's Boulos Investment Group, he became the Chairman of Intercontinental Bank S.A. (1996–1998) and negotiated a merger with [[Sogebank]], one of Haiti's largest banks. In 2003, Dr. Boulos orchestrated the re-engineering of one of the oldest daily newspapers in Haiti, Le Nouveau Matin. From 2000 to 2010, Dr. Boulos created and developed Delimart, a chain of supermarkets, Autoplaza, a leading car dealership and Megamart, a membership food discount store. Recently, he organized renovation of a landmark Hotel in Haiti, El Rancho, re-opening as an NH. ==Philanthropy== Dr. Boulos is a longstanding champion of social improvement in Haiti. In 1992, he founded the Fond de Parrainage National (FPN), which today finances the education of close to 20,000 elementary school children in Haiti. He is still its Chairman. From 1982 to 1996, he was Chair and General Manager of the Centers for Development and Health, a Haitian non-governmental organization that provides services and integrated health care to the populations of disadvantaged areas of the country since 1974. Under his leadership, the Center developed and managed the most comprehensive health program in Haiti, providing health and social services to 550,000 people. He is also the founder of Haiti's Child Health Institute, a research institution and the Haitian Institute for Community Health, a training institution.http://www.cdshaiti.org/ ==Reconstructing Haiti== Dr. Boulos believes the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]] presents new opportunities for Haiti, especially for business growth and sustainable development.http://www.haitiaccountability.org/ Dr. Boulos proposed that donors allocate at least 50% of all funds and guarantees to formal [[Small and Medium Enterprises]] (SME) and micro-enterprise financing, encourage broad ownership of larger companies, and implement SME set-asides, especially in the housing and construction sectors. Behind his recommendations, Dr. Boulos' principles are those of accountability, equality, and "independence from international aid." Dr. Boulos is active in the reconstruction of Haiti, and is the Business Sector Representative for the HRIC - Haiti Reconstruction Commission, or also known as the CIRH - Commission Interimaire Pour La Reconstruction D'Haiti, which is co-chaired by former U.S. President [[Bill Clinton]] and Haitian Prime Minister [[Jean-Max Bellerive]].http://haitirewired.wired.com/profiles/blogs/list-of-representatives-haiti?xg_source=activity"But with foreign aid flowing and a sympathetic world watching, Boulos envisions a new Haiti: one focused on quickly creating jobs while purging its ruling class of the cronyism that helped make this one of the world's poorest countries."https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/02/14/AR2010021403322.html ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boulos, Reginald}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Haitian businesspeople]] [[Category:Haitian people of Lebanese descent]] [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:MIT Sloan School of Management alumni]] [[Category:Tulane University School of Public Health and Tropical Medicine alumni]]

{{Orphan|date=November 2016}}
{{course assignment | course = Education Program:University College London/MSIN1003 Information World (Autumn 2014) | term = 2014 Q3}} In [[business]], a '''revenue center''' is a [[division (organization)|division]] that gains revenue from product sales or service provided.<ref>{{cite web|title=revenue center|url=http://www.businessdictionary.com/definition/revenue-center.html|publisher=Businessdictionary.com|accessdate=23 October 2011}}</ref> The manager in revenue center is accountable for revenue only.
==Overview== A revenue center is one of the five divisions of a responsibility center – cost center, revenue center, profit center, contribution center and investment center.<ref name="Tulsian2006">{{cite book|author=P. Tulsian|title=Cost Accounting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w2kbrUHIuk0C&pg=SA1-PA15|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=1 July 2006|publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill Education|isbn=978-0-07-062043-8|pages=1.15}}</ref> Cost centers, like revenue centers, only monitor costs, thereby making them a counterpart to the revenue center.<ref name="Jensen1998">{{cite book|author=Michael C. Jensen|title=Foundations of Organizational Strategy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B-TP-fxGJDQC&pg=PA351|accessdate=20 October 2014|year=1998|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-64342-0|page=351}}</ref> Revenue centers only measure the output (in fiscal standings) and are therefore marketing establishments which are exempt from profit generation and accountability thereof.<ref name="casestudyinmarketing">{{cite book|author=Pradip Kumar Sinha|title=Case Study in Marketing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sz1xH9eYZMEC&pg=PA31|accessdate=20 October 2014|year=2007|publisher=Nirali Prakashan|isbn=978-93-80064-10-9|page=31}}</ref> In a revenue center performance is measured by comparing actual sales to projected ones (as well as number of sales or revenue per time scale). Quota and budget comparisons are also used as a performance indicator.<ref name="NeedlesCrosson2013">{{cite book|author1=Belverd Needles|author2=Susan Crosson|title=Managerial Accounting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=te4WAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA250|accessdate=22 October 2014|date=19 February 2013|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=1-285-67528-2|page=250}}</ref><ref name="Jawaharlal2002">{{cite book|author=Jawahar Lal|title=Cost Accounting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zMr8a2gQ-4UC&pg=PA844|accessdate=22 October 2014|edition=3|date=1 August 2002|publisher=Tata McGraw-Hill Education|isbn=978-0-07-048274-6|page=844}}</ref>
A revenue center has costs, however to the manager of a revenue center this is of little importance as revenue is his sole performance indicator.<ref name="BushJohnston1998">{{cite book|author1=James W. Bush|author2=Daniel Johnston|title=International Oil Company Financial Management in Nontechnical Language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sYIqxibXy1kC&pg=PA85|accessdate=22 October 2014|date=1 January 1998|publisher=PennWell Books|isbn=978-0-87814-597-3|page=85}}</ref> Not all costs are ignored in a revenue center. For example, the manager of a revenue center is responsible for the expenses of his department (such as maintenance costs).<ref name="Palanivelu2007">{{cite book|author=V.R. Palanivelu|title=Accounting for Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OzkX7v7wQBEC&pg=PA406|accessdate=21 October 2014|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Firewall Media|isbn=978-81-318-0119-2|page=406}}</ref> In a sales office (the most widespread example of a revenue center), maintenance costs can be construed as rent, salaries, taxes and security. However, any costs related to product sale and manufacturing are not included in such expenses.<ref name="GHOSH2005">{{cite book|author=N. GHOSH|title=MANAGEMENT CONTROL SYSTEMS|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mLk11itaLrIC&pg=PA23|accessdate=20 October 2014|date=1 January 2005|publisher=PHI Learning Pvt. Ltd.|isbn=978-81-203-2844-0|page=23}}</ref> A revenue center becomes a profit center if the latter is encompassed, thus making a profit center a blend of both a cost and revenue center.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Mahesh Kulkarni|author2=Suhas Mahajan|title=Management Accounting|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JFdzpFzpVtUC&pg=SA6-PA8|accessdate=19 October 2014|year=2008|publisher=Nirali Prakashan|isbn=978-93-80064-15-4|pages=6.8}}</ref>
In a revenue center the manager usually has control over issues regarding marketing and sales. This is delegated to him because both of the spheres require extensive knowledge that is explicit to the local market. However, the revenue center manager will not be given control over decision on quantity or product mix. If the manager is given control over these decisions problems can arise (see below).<ref name="casestudyinmarketing"/>
Technological advancements have been able to reduce expenses in revenue centers as well as bring non-traditional (online) revenue centers to non-retail companies that work in manufacturing or service industries. This can be done by setting up websites which offer products directly from the supplier. This reduces cost by shortening the distribution channel and cuts out wholesalers and retailers.<ref name="website">{{cite web|title=What is a Revenue Center|url=http://www.wisegeek.com/what-is-a-revenue-center.htm|year=2014|publisher=wiseGEEK|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref>
==Problems with Revenue Centers==
One of the biggest problems in a revenue center is that costs are mostly ignored. If costs are not monitored by another division of the business, profits can be hindered. Furthermore, the manager of a revenue center does not have the insight required for marketing decisions, consequently responsibility for a marketing decision cannot be given to a revenue center manager. Setting prices on products or services is an example of revenue center managers being unable to undertake marketing decisions.<ref name="casestudyinmarketing"/>
It is easy to calculate the performance of a revenue center as revenue is the only variable being performed against. However, this means that performance evaluations are also limited to one variable which is usually not enough to see the performance of a business division.<ref name="KinneyRaiborn2012">{{cite book|author1=Michael Kinney|author2=Cecily Raiborn|title=Cost Accounting: Foundations and Evolutions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nm3uBQP7cTIC&pg=PA509|accessdate=18 October 2014|date=31 May 2012|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=1-111-97172-2|page=509}}</ref>
Pure revenue centers hardly exist. This is due to the fact that costs cannot be completely ignored. Usually (as stated above) revenue center managers control expenses.<ref name="KinneyRaiborn2012"/>
Revenue center managers should not be allowed to make marketing decisions. For example, if a revenue center manager is allowed to set the revenue target, he will maximise revenue. This will cause the marginal revenue to become zero.<ref name="BushJohnston1998"/>
In large companies with multiple products revenue centers will be responsible for meeting revenue target for each product. The problem will arise if all revenues are added together into a total of all products. The revenue manager will then be able to make up any losses in revenue by taking the revenue from the ones that outperformed the targets to the ones that underperformed, thereby causing a loss in overall profits.<ref name="BushJohnston1998"/>
Businesses may decide to open revenue centers when entering new markets or industries. The initial cost of these centers is high and it is highly likely that a lot of time is required in order for those centers to become profitable and cover the start-up expenditures.<ref name="BushJohnston1998"/>
==Examples of Revenue Centers==
The following is a list of some examples of revenue centers.
*Sales office<ref name="BushJohnston1998"/> *Amazon's eCommerce department<ref name="NeedlesCrosson2013"/> *Hertz's national car reservation center<ref name="NeedlesCrosson2013"/> *In hotels:<ref name="Pizam2010">{{cite book|author=Abraham Pizam|title=International Encyclopedia of Hospitality Management|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B2smECX7Sn4C&pg=PA578|accessdate=19 October 2014|year=2010|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|isbn=978-1-85617-714-6|page=578}}</ref> **Rooms division **Restaurants **Bars **Lounges **Banqueting facilities **Telephone **Gift shops **Valet parking **Laundry
==See also== *[[Responsibility center]] * [[Cost center (business)|Cost or Expense center]] * [[Profit center]] * [[Investment center]]
